reviewText: Product exterior - 3" x 1" x 1" or so. Picking it up you can feel a little weight to it, you can tell it is not a cheaply made charger.After plugging in my phone and iPad 2 into the charger, both notified me that they were charging. I charged my devices on my drive home for work, phone charged 20% and my iPad 10% in about 15 min.I make a few trips to Colorado per year (300 miles) and will use this every trip. The kids love to use the iPad in the car, but the battery will be out before we get to our destination. Now we will be able to charge it like we had it at home plugged in.This is great for those on the go people that need a good quick rapid charge for your phone, but also need to charge an iPad. This charger will work with any device that can be charged from a USB cord(5v).Anker gave me this product in exchange for my honest feedback.

reviewText: With so many cheap "import" units for just a few dollars, it's really within your best interest to spend a little extra and get something with some quality. This unit fits the bill nicely, so much I bought one to test and ended up ordering two more. I have no tested this up to the rated 2.4amp claim, but at 1.4 amps with my Nexus 7 tablet it is still putting out a nice stable voltage. I then hooked up my Nexus 5 phone at the same time and it was fast charing both.I hooked it up to my bench power supply and fed it 13.92 volts. I then connected my USB current / volt meter and then my Nexus 7 tablet. It was putting out 1.41amps at 5.22 volts. Not bad, that's about as I've ever seen my Nexus 7 draw while charging. When I then connected my phone (which charges around 1.2 amps) the voltage stayed nice and steady. This thing works - and I've VERY pleased.It's also quite small -- when inserted into the lighter all that sticks out is the little cube end with the two USB ports. There is no silly and ugly LED light to blind you at night either.Highly recommended as I have found all Anker products to be well designed and work well. I purchased the 6000mah portable power bank and a 3000mah one for my mother and another for my father and all of those devices work great too.

reviewText: I just bought one of these car chargers last week and had the chance to use it over the weekend. I'm very pleased. It does what it promised. Thanks to PowerIQ, it can charge any device on any port, rather than having to put Apple devices in some ports and Androids in others for best charging efficiency -- I've always felt I was getting only half the use out of those devices.I have an app on my android tablet that tells me what my amps are coming in when I plug the device into a charger. When I've used ports that were designated for Apple, even though the port was rated at 2.1 to 2.4 amps, it would read lower coming in than the Android port that was was listed as 1.0 to 1.2 amps. With these chargers, I get the same amps reading on every port.It was such a joy this weekend to be able to do mapping, surf the web, and charge my tablet all at the same time. My previous car charge was lucky to keep my tablet from losing charge its charge level while using it.

reviewText: 07/07/14 - Anker contacted me and asked if they could send me a replacement. I was happy that Anker wasn't just keeping my money and ignoring me. I did, and I'm pleased to say that it works as good as my first one.I'm adjusting my rating from 1 star to 4 - just because of their great customer service. My son was using a different lower wattage charger at the same time and it is still working fine. In fact, I took his to replace this Anker one. reviewText: I'm a little confused by the reviews stating that there is an Apple port and a non-Apple port.  This unit has PowerIQ, which eliminates the need for such labels, because any device can be plugged into any port, and the charger is intelligent enough to send right level of power to the device.  That is actually the reason why I bought this charger.For those reviewers that mention the Apple and non-Apple ports, I believe you are describing a different, non-PowerIQ model.Having said that, this charger works perfectly, and will charge anything you can throw at it, without the need for charge-only cables or having to make sure you plugged into the right port.  Two iPads?  no problem.  Two Androids?  no problem.  Feels very high quality and I expect it to last.  Highly recommend.

reviewText: .Good features and function, full-speed charging for phones and many (not all) tablets.- - - Speed Matters - - -Sometimes you need to charge in a hurry. Even if a charger "works with your device" it may be painfully slow. Get one that will charge your devices at full speed (like the charger that came with your device).For starters, the "Amps" need to be high enough. That's usually 1 Amp for smartphones, about 2 Amps for large tablets. (A higher amp charger is always OK.) Some chargers are only 1/2 Amp (500mA).Problem is, Apple devices use their own rules to decide charging speed. A designed-for-Apple charger may be slow to charge non-Apple devices, and vice versa, even if its Amp rating is high enough.Anker gets it right by optimizing one port for Apple products (including iPad) and the second port for non-Apple products. The two ports make it versatile, even if you never charge two devices at once. However, the Non-Apple port is limited to 1.5 amps, which could mean reduced charging speed for some 9-10" tablets.PROs:* Full speed charging (claimed) for most USB-charged devices* Two ports separately optimized for Apple and non-Apple devices- Branded product - Amazon reviews apply to this exact item.- 18 month warrantyOKs:- Reasonable price (but prices fluctuate)- Appearance & detail: Good- No power-on light - could be a pro or a con- Reasonably secure fit in your 12v socket - could be better- Port labels (Apple & Android) are hard to read- Ports are "upside down" (just use it with Anker logo down)- User manual: Complete and clear- No cable includedCONs:- Android port limited to 1.5 Amp output (according to Anker specs)- - - Dimensions - - -0.93" x 1.03" x 3"Protrudes 1.5 to 1.75 inches from 12v socket when in use.- - - Alternatives - - -There are dozens of other car chargers on amazon. Most are either lower power (1/2 Amp or 1-Amp - not suitable for tablets) or are designed for Apple products only (may charge non-Apple devices slowly).The PowerGen is quite similar with some advantages and disadvantages (see Note 1)Multi- . . . . . . . . . . . . AmpsProtocol . . Flush . . . per Port------- . . . -------- . . . --------Yes . . . . . . No . . . . . 3.1 - 3.1. . . .PowerGen Dual USB 3.1 Amp Car ChargerYes?. . . . . . Yes . . . . 2.1 - 1.0. . . .USAMS Compact 3.1A Dual USB Car ChargerYes . . . . . . No . . . . . 2.1 - 1.5. . . . Anker 3.6 Amp (this charger)"Multi-protocol" = They appear to charge various Apple and non-Apple devices at rated Amperage"Flush" = Sticks out 3/8" or less from the 12v socket.I hope to update this over time. Leave comments.- - - Disclosure - - -The manufacturer gave me this product for review. I believe my review is impartial.- - - Notes - - -Note 1: Anker features, as compared to PowerGen- Higher total output claimed (if charging 2.1-amp and 1.5-amp devices simultaneously)- Non-Apple port is limited to 1.5 amps; less than full power for some non-Apple tablets (vs 3.1 Amps PowerGen)- No power-on light (You may prefer a power light, or not.)- More compact (sticks out the same amount, but slimmer profile)- White/Gray only (PowerGen comes in Black or White)~~~ Comments & questions welcome ~~~

reviewText: I purchased this for the high wattage output and it certainly lives up to its claims. I bought a pair of these, using exclusively on a road trip with the wife and kids. For instance, the one in the front of the van had my iphone 5 with navigation going along with my wife's ipad who was watching movies. Both stayed charged at 100 % during use. When only charging one device and the device wasn't in use, it charged quicker than a home charger. They also have a look and feel of durability. These are well worth the price paid; I will no longer again buy the cheapest car charger I can find.

reviewText: First, let me say that this thing seems amazingly well built.  For such a tiny little thing, it feels like it was made by superman squeezing diamonds until they turned into a charger for my phone.  The packaging and everything to do with this little guy impressed me to no end, and made me immediately look up anything else I could buy from this company, so I was quite disappointed when I plugged it into my car and it didn't work.  I guess I will return it, and hope the next one works.  I will update based on that experience.Edit 2014/02/24Service from this company is phenomenal.  I received an email from them very briefly after posting my review.  Long story short they sent me a replacement and have already checked to make sure the second one met my satisfaction.  I can still only raise the rating to three stars, as it seems something in the design of this keeps it from keeping constant contact in the vehicle I would like to use it in.  This seems to be vehicle specific, in which other chargers work fine in this vehicle, and this charger works in some other vehicles.  It unfortunately does not work for the one I intended to use it with, so that is disappointing. The charger does work however.  I feel bad not giving this charger a hire rating, but the fact remains that this is the only charger that I have found that does not work in our Scion.

reviewText: Outstanding, high-end, solid built cat charger.  No guesses if port is "apple" or "android" or if device is 1A or 2A - two USB charging ports, device has logic to detect and safely charge 1A and 2A devices, have tried several (at my own expense" chargers - works solid with Samsung S3 and specially S5 (works with iPhone 5 too) - dozen of vendors that make charges claim they "work" with "all devices" which is true - "work" is a tricky marketing term.  I want the phone to actually charge, safely charge and not just barely keep the phone alive while it's "working" on the charging part.  This charger is superb for any Apple or Android device.

title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: 4.5 stars. 2 ports in one.  There seemed to be a lot of negative reviews due to folks not reading the description RE output wattage.  They have designed the two circuits to match the specs of the products.  The only flaw IMO is that the lettering on the front is very difficult to read. So make sure you know which port is which, or plug your devices in, BEFORE you start driving (or pull over).  I keep this item in the glovebox as a backup for my Samsung Galaxy SIII and in case anyone needs to charge their iPhone in my car.  I use the Samsung factory charger primarily.  I have not noticed a significant difference in the charging times.  Neither charger is particularly fast, but that is the way they are supposed to operate to optimize battery life. As described if you attach 2 devices at the same time they will take longer to charge. It will also get warm so you should unplug it when you are not charging your device. 'Rapid chargers' might charge your phone/device faster but they are not optimal for you battery and some may cause damage to your battery if they don't match the design specs.  In summary, this is a good product which can charge multiple devices stand alone or together.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: I ordered four of these for use at our company, and gave them to the people who are out in their vehicles most of the day, using their phones heavily. I asked for feedback from each of them, and they all say these chargers work great. One person reported that it charged his phone to 100% in 20 minutes.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: This charger will charge 1 device fairly quickly compared to other car chargers.  If you have two devices plugged in, the charging time is exponentially decreased.  If you have a device that has GPS enabled and are using Google Maps or Waze Nav software, this charger does not have enough power to charge the device.  The device will decrease in battery level slowly when GPS Nav software is enabled.Is this device worth $10.00 plus tax?????.....I would say that most car chargers are made poorly and are only worth at the very most $5.00.  This device is honestly worth about $6.00If the charger can charge two devices simultaneously with GPS turned on for both devices, then it would be worth the $10.FYI....I VERY RARELY write reviews.....

title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: I bought this to use with my Galaxy S4.  There are days where I use Navigation extensively and it uses a significant amount of power.  If I just use the battery, I find that Navigation discharges the battery about 30%/hour.  When I use my cheapy cigarette lighter adapter, the battery would still discharge, but at a rate of 15%/hour.  When I use this product (with my Samsung USB cable that came with the phone), I can use Navigation and actually charge the battery at a rate of 15%/hour (my test started at 39% battery).  I haven't experimented yet, but I'm sure if I wasn't using Navigation and the phone's screen was off, the battery charge rate would be higher.  I've also used the USB cable that came with my old HTC Evo 3D, and it seems to work just as well as the Samsung cable.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: Very few adapter chargers have this current capacity and none has better fit and finish quality ( and they cost more).

reviewText: This works great for all sorts of devices needing charging in the car.  Have had not problems with it in 6+ months.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: My love story with Anker starts with my Anker Astro 3E. I had bought Anker batteries before for mobile phones, but never saw them for much more than a good OEM replacement. They have since grown to an excellent company with awesome products.This little charger is an awesome unit. It would be nice if Anker threw in at least one USB cable for it, but I can't complain. I got some really nice MediaBridge cables for a good price (6ft cable 6 dlls each).Charged two Galaxy SIII from about 40% to 100% in a little under an hour. Keep in mind, it charged them BOTH AT THE SAME TIME. Exactly what the doctor ordered. You might think 10 dlls is expensive with so many other options out there, but I can tell you, you won't get 2.4A on each port on a quality charger for that money. And that's just what this is, a QUALITY charger!Also got an Anker 2nd Gen Astro 6000mAh for my wife (I was going to get her the smaller 3000mAh version, but she's really into Ingress now so battery life is a must), all of them awesome products. I would definitely recommend any and all Anker products :)
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: I received this product direct from Anker after a problem with their other dual port USB Car charger.This product looks and feels well made, it charges my Note 3 and S4 as quick as the Samsung wall charger even when I am using the phones to navigate.I only gave this product 4 stars because I think there is room for improvement. First, I have to push it hard so it will reach the contact of my car's socket, this may be due to the spring mechanisms on the side of the unit being new and still stiff, though I never encountered this problem with other car chargers. Second, there is no indication that it is fully seated inside the cigarette socket because it doesn't have any light indicator so you have to look at your phone if it is charging. Third, it doesn't come with a cable. These to me are only minor flaws, and I have to say I am only nitpicking.Kudos to Anker for their great Rep (I forgot her name)  and their produKt support.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: This is the first car charger that I have reviewed and used that featured device-specific ports; Apple and Android. But, this is great since the Apple port sends out 2.1 amps and the Android sends out 1.5 amps of power. Adding up to 3.6 amps, which  allows you to charge your device quickly with no long waiting times.Taking a closer look at the car charger you will notice that the USB ports are labeled with "Apple" and "Android." As well as the Anker logo on the very top. Which is very well positioned on the gadget itself.There's not much I can say about the product besides that it works very well in whatever environment I placed it in.  Currently, it's support Apple iPads, iPhones, iPads, Samsung Galaxy S2, S3, Note 2, Droid RAZR MAXX, HTC One X, V, and S, plus GPS, PSP, Kindle, Kindle Fire, Nexus 7 and much more.

reviewText: In my experience, just having this device plugged into my car causes the transponder that opens my garage gate NOT to work, and my garage gate does not open.  When I pull this device out of the car socket, the gate immediately opens.  It's obviously not hard to pull the device out, but a device like this really shouldn't cause this kind of interference.Outside of that, the big pro is that this device charges my Samsung Note 2 at the highest speed it can be charged (a trick that the Anker household chargers still do NOT do).  The con is that for a family that uses Android phones exclusively, the second (Apple) port does not deliver as high performance.

title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: Amazing power on this one. Tottally Anker fan. Started with the Anker 21W Solar Charger, and it blew me off with the way it charged all my phones and even my tablet. Then I bought the 15.000 mAh external battery, and it is also amazing.Now finally, bought 2 of these little car chargers, one for my own truck, and another for the company's truck, 'cause I do aprox 15.000 kilometers/year visiting clients. So that means, I'm almost 10 hours per day on the road. And I want all my gadgets to be charged all the time.My first try was, connecting both my Galaxy Note 3 (3.200 mAh battery), and my tablet Galaxy Note 10.1 2014 (8.220 mAh battery) at the same time. Both were on, and with 50% charge at the beginning.In less than 2 hours, they both charged all the way to 100%! And unlike other chargers I've tried before, it didn't even got hot. Barely warm. For the size of my batteries, I know it gave minimun 2 Amps in both ports, at the same time. Which is awesome!One port is labeled Apple, and the other, it says Android. As I could read, if you connect android, you will have less current in the apple port. So I connected the Note 3 there. But I don't think it will even make a difference. Both ports charges great and fast.Tottally recommend this one. More than happy!
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: This is by far the best car charger that I have found.  Most car chargers are low amperage, averaging 1.8 amps for 1 Port and it splits it if you have both ports plugged up.  With the larger batteries in mobile devices, that just doesn't cut it.  The devices will charge extremely slow, and some won't charge at all.  This charger pushes 2.4 amps (Max) per port simultaneously.  This allows you devices to charge at a much faster rate.  With other car chargers, if I was using the GPS on my Lumia 920, while charging, the battery would actually go down.  With this charger I can use the GPS while the phone is charging (Going up, not down) and have my wife's iPhone charging at the same time.  It averages out that in standby this charger will charge my 920 about 3-4% in 10 minutes and my wife's iPhone about 6%.  Since it doesn't split the 2.4 amps between the two ports, I can plug in both of my Nephews' iPads and they can play games while we are on long trips and they never get upset about their battery dying.  This is a great charger, and it is built extremely well.  I plan on buying a couple more of them for other family members that have new age devices.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: Back in the old days (a few years ago), anything that charged off a USB cord used only the trickle of power that PCs with USB 2.0 provided.  (About 5 volts x 0.5 amps = 2.5 watts).Now, however, we have power-hungry devices like the Kindle, the iPad, and various android tablets and related gadgets that will take more power if they can get it.  I've tried a bunch of car chargers, and when Anker offered me the this one in return for an honest review, I jumped at it, and am glad I did.  I'm leaving this in my car as my regular charger, and my old one is on a short trip to my "extra electronics" drawer.This car charger is built for people who want to fast charge two simultaneous devices: an iOS device with a port that puts out up to 2.1 amps, and an "android" device from a second port that puts out up to 1.5 amps.  (If you assume 5 volts, that gets you to 18 watts overall.)I don't have an android device or a Kindle, so I plugged my iPhone 4S into the "android" port and my iPad 3 into the "apple" port.  Charging was as good as I could reasonably hope - the iPad went from 17% charge to 22% in a 20 minute drive, which is pretty good given its oversized battery.What I liked:- This puts out a lot of power to two ports.  If you need power under these specs, or if your device can adjust, it's nice, particularly since an iPad is so hard to fast charge.- The ports are wired separately, so using both at once won't reduce the charge in the individual ports.- It's relatively low profile (sticks out about an inch), a good looking apple-ish white, and fits well.Some observations:- This has no charging light.  That doesn't bug me (I'm more interested in whether my DEVICE says it's charging than whether the plug does), but was a surprise.- No cables are included, but I assume you have plenty of USB cables for your devices at this point.- Most devices are smart about how much power they take, but if you have an older device that is somehow not supposed to charge from a fast feed, I'd be careful.- It's kind of a pain to tell which port is the "apple" port and which one is the "android" port, so I circled my apple port with sharpie.All in all, highly recommended if this fits your power needs.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: My Anker 18W 3.6A Car Charger arrived the other day and my initial test was to take my iPad 2 with 52% battery life and see how much it would charge on a 40 minute car ride with a dead Plantronics bluetooth earpiece (the Voyager Pro) charging in the Android slot at the same time.  Both products did charge, and the iPad 2 was charged from 52% to 74% battery life in about 40 minutes which isn't actually bad from a car charger at all.  Based on the 22% charge in 40 minutes, I would presume you can charge from dead to 100% in about 3 1/2 hours or less.I really like that you can charge both a Smartphone and tablet at the same time (tested the iPhone 4S in the Android port while iPad was in the Apple port and still charged fine).Wish you could charge an iPad in the Apple port and a Kindle Fire HD or Google Nexus 7 in the Android port at the same time, but this would be too much output for this charger.  That would make it 5 stars in my book.The charger did get warm after the 40 minute charge, but I didn't feel like it was in danger of burning up or anything.

reviewText: I'm very happy with this car charger, because it does exactly what it's designed to do: charge Smart Phones and iPads and iPods and... DA DA DA ... Kindle products quickly.PROS:1) I've charged my Kindle Fire on the go -- and it's truly a *fast* charge.2) My iPod Touch also charged perfectly. (I keep an extra cord in the car at all times, because I plug my iPod into my stereo system.)3) This little charger saved my friend's Samsung Galaxy S2's day with a charge on the fly.CONS:1) I'd think twice before attempting to charge older products, because it *is* a full-speed charger and may not be compatible with older technology.This is a great little charger at a great price! title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: There is a lot to like about this charger. 1st and foremost, it is amongst those few chargers that both clearly indicate what types of devices it will charge and supports the vast majority of both Apple and Android devices.  This is a lot more rare than many realize, as it is impossible, without some sort of switch/configuration, to have one port on a charger that supports both Apple products and Android products.This charger goes the route that a few others have and allocates one port to Apple products and one to Android.  This is great for flexibility, and while when the idea was first introduced I thought it was a great solution, over time I've grown somewhat disappointed with it.  My family, like most families, have settled into being a one-OS family (Android in our case).  So what good does that 2nd port, which only supports Apple, do if all my devices are Android?Yes, I know that I can use special "charging cables" to make ports designed for Apple products work well with Android devices, but personally I find that a weak solution.  It means I have to carry two different types of cables on a trip, one for an actual USB connection to a PC and one for charging.  I'd rather not have to do that.This charger also has another new feature, one that I've only seen on one other charger, the PowerGen 15W charger.  Most multi-port chargers, even those who support different devices on different ports, use one voltage converter to power all the ports (called "bridged" from this point forward).  The downside of a bridged solution is that if one device pulls too much power, the other device suffers.  This device has two entirely independent converters, so if one device pulls a lot, it will have no effect on the others.  Kudos to Anker for taking the lead on that.The downside for this device is that both ports do not have the 2.1 amps of current I would like to see, that the most power hungry devices require.  The Apple port is spec'ed to 2.1 amps, but the Android port is only spec'ed to 1.5 amps.  This means that people with 10" Android tablets won't be pulling the full power they could, even if the other device is only an iPod.  The bridged products don't suffer similarly.  However, it is worth noting that this device is better than the one other device that has it, which only has two 1.5 amp ports.As for whether this delivers on its specs, my power draw testing passed with flying colors.  The USB spec is that the voltage shouldn't dip below 4.75 volts.  The 2.1 amp port was at 4.81 volts when I was pulling nearly 2.2 amps. The 1.5 amp port held at 4.90 volts even when I pushed beyond 1.6 amps.  This makes this the best performing charger I've tested.  As an added bonus, when I did push the unit significantly beyond it's amperage specs, the ports went into auto-shutoff preventing damage to the device, yet another positive for this device.I had two minor dislikes for me personally:  It doesn't support the HP Touchpad (I recognize few of you will care) and it doesn't have a power LED.  I know some will like that, as they don't like the distracting light, particularly at night.  For me however, I prefer a light (not too bright of course) so that I know the device is working (or at least claims to be).Overall, for people with an iPad and an Android phone, or an iPhone and a 7" Android tablet, or a her iPhone and his Android phone, or an iPhone and a lower power device (less than 0.5 amps) or is willing to buy a "charging cable" I think you'll be happy with the device.  Not only does it deliver a lot of current, its good construction and compact size also are positives on its side that you'll like.For me personally, this will replace my 15W bridged device from PowerGen for when I have one Apple and one Android device, but I'll keep using the 10W bridged device from Bracketron for when I've got two Android devices or am lugging around my HP touchpad.For device manufacturers, if you want my coveted 5-star rating, this is what you have to do:1. Deliver 2.1 amps to both ports2. Make each device configurable (a small switch, etc.) to be either Android or Apple3. Have good ergonomics/quality/compact size like this Anker4. Support the HP Touchpad (OK, you don't really have to do that, but I'd really appreciate it anyway)Notes on the devices I tested with:-HTC Evo 4G LTE - showed "AC charging"-Kyocera Rise - showed "AC charging"-LG Optimus S - showed "AC charging"-4th gen iPod Touch - charged correctly-HP Touchpad - didn't charge correctly-Breadboard with cut cables, power resistors and a fluke DVM used for power draw/voltage testsFull disclosure: Anker shipped/gave me this product for free in exchange for my honest feedback.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: When I first bought this device, I thought it  would be a sound buy based on other reviews. It's built sturdy and supposedly packed more than adequate power to properly, quickly and fully charge 2 Samsung GS4s simultaneously with no effort. The "IQ" technology was also exactly what I was looking for.It also does not have a lighted display telling you it's on, which I personally liked as your devices tell you that already. However, if your vehicles charge port is not switched (Constant On), you may forget it's plugged in and may result in a dead car battery if left in for a while. Finally, I liked the fact it can't be seen reducing the chance of attracting thieves because it's not lit and is seated more than half way in my port.The problem is that only after 3 short uses, and not even both ports, it failed without warning. It was never left on for prolonged periods and my vehicles electrical system was checked and the device was getting between 12 and 13.75 volts, well within the devices design parameters.This device was only 12 dollars plus shipping.My advice, spend a little more money on a quality name brand reliable product to charge your expensive devices. Steer clear of this brand.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: I haven't had much luck with car chargers. They always seem to stop working fairly quickly. I've stopped using them and just resorted to making sure my device is fully charged before leaving the house. I didn't have high hopes for this charger either until I was amazed at how fast it charged my daughter's iPod Touch 5th generation. I don't know if we just got lucky but my daughter's iPod was completely dead before we got into the van. We plugged it in and her iPod Touch was completely charged in less than 15 minutes. I'm being completely honest. She was like mom that was quick, and I'm like what was quick? She then stated that her iPod Touch had finished charging. I was amazed so this car charger definitely gets kudos for how fast it charges devices. I also tested it on my iPad 2, Android phone, iPod Touch 4th generation and an iPhone 4S. Each device charged fairly quickly. I also like the fact that the car charger worked up front and behind the driver's side. I have a panel of outlets in my van to plugin devices such as Playstation etc. My kids riding in the back can choose to use either the electrical outlet or the AC Adapter outlet. I have a 2012 Chrysler Town & Country. I would recommend getting this charger especially since it has the dual slots for Android and iOS devices. It also charges the devices fairly quickly which I'm very happy about!
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: If you're like me, you probably already have one or two of the single port chargers with no particular energy rating on it. title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: This little USB charger seems to be very well made. It feels solid and fits securely into the 12v socket in my car's dashboard. This is in contrast to some cheaply made 12 volt automotive accessories whose plugs fit so loose and sloppy that they are constantly vibrating loose and have to be repeatedly pushed back in to the socket.Both sockets deliver at least enough power to charge my Samsung Galaxy Player (a 4" screen device).  I don't yet own a 7" or 10" tablet to test if the Anker charger can deliver enough juice to charge those larger, more power-hungry devices.  I will update this review if/when I have a tablet to test on this charger. I also don't own any Apple devices so I can't test if the Apple-specific upper port is delivering Apple-specific electric power ("I-juice" I suppose you would call this).The Anker charger got only slightly warm to the touch while powering my 4" Galaxy player. If I get a chance to test it with a 10" tablet I will be sure to check it for heat build up and report that in my update.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: Ah, to be rid of dedicated car chargers. Now, I am. This will work with ALL our devices: Android phone, Apple phone, Samsung tablet, and on and on. What a TERRIFIC idea, and product.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: This is my 3rd Anker product purchase from Amazon, and with myriads of Android devices in the household (more than a dozen, yes, that's excessive!), I can attest that this car charger is what you want plugged in your 12v outlet.I measured the current flowing into my Android device with "Battery Charging Source and Current" app. There are other apps that would do the same, but some devices might NOT be capable to report any charging current, so your mileage may vary. My Galaxy S4 and a few other Android devices do. Other reviewers with workbench 12v outlet would be able to do more accurate reading, but for my purpose, the app suffices.With a good cable, a single Galaxy S4 can pull 1960 mA (~2A) from either port. Again, CABLE MATTERS. If you read reviews that say that they're not getting high current, chances are they are using sub-standard cable. It's trial and error with cables, unfortunately. Good, shorter cable (6 inch to 1ft) would most likely be able to deliver high current, but it depends on the quality. Longer cable can deliver high current if it's shielded. The 6ft cables that come with the later Galaxy and Nexus devices are good cables.Pros:1) High amperage supplied power to the device (with good cable)2) Not too bulky3) Good price4) Anker has a great customer service from my own personal experienceCons:1) Label is so tiny (doesn't matter for me cause all of my devices are Android)2) Long form factor. In my VWs, the 12v outlet is hidden and recessed horizontally (top-down) in the center console, so this isn't a problem, but in other cars where the outlet is vertical, it might stick out a bit too far.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: I wanted this Anker 18W charger since we have multiple smartphones and iPads, and only one 12V outlet in the car (yeah I know, first world problems). We make a lot of long drives to my treatment appointments in a major city two hours away, and in that time a phone used as a GPS or an iPad that wasn't charged up the night before can easily die. There are very few chargers on the market that have dual ports that have the kind of power output (18W) necessary for plugging in an iPad and another smartphone. You'll be familiar with the "not charging" indication you get on the iPad when your charger doesn't have enough power, and the iPad will charge at a snail's pace, if at all.They say to never judge a book by its cover. I wasn't impressed, initially with how the Anker 18W charger was packaged. It had slipped out of the cardboard holder and was just loose in the box. Coupled with the rather plain packaging, it just screams poor design. However, it is a product I obtained for its purpose, not for its packaging.The charger is quite compact, which is wonderful. I am used to having to buy bulky chargers that get in the way of the gear shift. The sleek design is well labeled; it's easy to see which port is Apple-specific, and which is Android/other. I've both other multi-chargers that may confuse some, as they are simply labelled A and NA.I had a chance to test it out the other day on a long car ride. I wanted to play around on my iPad while my mom wanted to charge her iPhone. I plugged the iPad in to the Apple port and it immediately displayed "Charging," so it was getting enough output (at least 10 watts, or 2.1amps). The iPhone has an iOS higher than 5, and if you read the instruction manual, iPhones of iOS 5 or higher can indeed charge in the Android port at full power. Once the iPhone had charged, I swapped it out for my HTC EVO 4G LTE, and it also charged in the Android port with no issue. At this time I do not have a watt meter to measure power consumption during charge, but the iPad battery was charging 1% every few minutes.Thus, Anker's charger, in spite of the modest appearance, will more than "wow" you with its circuitry. Anker has thought of every variable in terms of product design. It does everything it claims, and upon reading the manual, it does even more: you can charge an iPad and an updated iPhone or Android at once, two iPhones, or an iPhone and and Android phone.In my opinion, they should highlight this feature, that the Android port can charge iPhones of iOS 5 or later at FULL CHARGE. I could find that benefit nowhere on the box.I surmise that since the iPad Mini is relatively new and also uses a 5W, 1.5amp charger, it should also charge fully on either the Apple or Android charging port. Anker could also update its instructions, and benefits to include the iPad mini.They have a great product that I highly recommend, and if they can get their packaging design to the next level, then they can more than compete at least on the shelf with "the big boys," the more well-known manufacturers. They certainly have the customer service and warranty to back up their offerings like the more well-known names: there is an 18 month manufacturer warranty on this charger, granting an unconditional replacement or refund. You can't go wrong with service like that.Anker gave me this product in exchange for my honest feedback.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: This device has 2 ports: Apple and Android. I found out that the Apple port pin 2,3 were not bridged and therefore when charging an Android device, it could only draw 500 mA (ok for a smartphone if it's not running all kind of apps, but most Android tablet won't work as 500 mA is not enough to charge a table). The Android port was fine as pin 2,3 were bridged (connected internally)so an Android smartphone or tablet can draw for up to 2A.I wish the description can be more clear or I wouldn't order it.Updated 10/18/2013:  After I posted the original review, Anker customer service contacted me immediately and helped me to get a refund. I applauded them. They are truly responsive providing a great service to their customer.  I procascinated for a week due to other committments and then I bought a Samsung Galaxy Note 2 to replace the Galaxy S2. I tried the Anker again and to my surprise, the Note 2 could draw 2A from both ports that the S2 couldn't.  I went online google it and true enough, the new Samsung is smart enough to draw the Apple port at full 2A required by the new Galaxy. So now I'm happy and I won't return it. This charger is high quality. The build is rock solid comparing to another flimsy one I bought.  It's highly recommended.

reviewText: This charger is a fine piece of equipment. I also like the fact that this DOESN'T have an LED indicator, as I've found those to be very annoying when driving at night.  I've had the opportunity to charge this on an Android phone, an iPhone (not mine), an iPod, and an iPad.  I will note that this seems to charge Apple products faster than other products.  This may be due to my Android phone though, as this charger still charges my phone faster than any other charger I've used.  You'll be hard pressed to find another charger with the output this one has on BOTH outlets, and this really is inexpensive.  The only gripe that I have is that Amazon only fulfilled the white version under Prime shipping (and that's just an Amazon inventory thing).

reviewText: Let me first say that I've enjoyed my Mediabridge car charger for the last several years. My iPhone4 uses the 1.0A outlet and my iPad uses the 2.4A outlet. It cost $10 and so the world was in harmony and life was good and simple...UNTIL (hang on to your seat folks!!!)The evil corporation that employs  me decided to upgrade my phone to the iPhone5S and my girlfriend decided that she needed a Samsung Galaxy with a screen bigger than a small flat screen TV.So now the requirement for power changes and while the Mediabridge works well, we are unable to charge both phones at the same time. It's not always that important that we have to charge at the same time, however, even if it was my (or her) iPad and/or one of our phone, then the situation would be about the same. On top of this, I always try to buy more than I need just in case the evil dark lords from the Nth Dimension (aka my boss [LUV YOU GUYS!!!]) decides I need to go through another upgrade, I wouldn't have to keep buying new charger, but just appropriate power cord.I started looking for something that would handle atleast 4.8A and came across this offering from Anker. I ordered one to test and see if I like it. Other reviews seems to give it high marks, so I figured its probably not a bad waste of $12.The charger arrived in a really nice box (I'm giving Anker an 'A' for presentation), but I was slightly disappointed as it seemed a bit cheapish on the build. Plastic casing looked cheap and weak, there was not a flexible side connector, but a sold piece, so I figured the performance would be as equally disappointing. HEY... its only $12 right, so who cares...So I plugged it into the car for a trip to Myrtle Beach with the girlfriend and friends and....OH MY DOG!! (sorry I'm also dyslexic) this thing charged ALL the phones in the car. It didn't seem to care what phone, or who by. It charged my iPad and her friend's iPod without a problem. While it ran a bit hot, it otherwise performed terrific without skipping a beat. Only problem was it can only charged two devices at any given time... so I decided to buy another one, but this time in black just to see if there's any difference. no difference.Overall, I can only say very positive things about this charger. YOU CANNOT GO WRONG WITH YOUR $12 IF YOU ARE LOOKING FOR A NEW CAR CHARGER!! this offering from Anker has to be it.Good luck on your purchase and I hope you enjoyed the humor. I truly hate boring reviews :)The Mediabridge will (alas) be retired to the kitchen drawer where all the chargers of yore goes to spend its last

reviewText: I bought and just received the Anker 18W / 2.4A + 2.0A (3.6A max) Dual Port USB Car Charger.This is advertised as 1 Apple port and 1 Android port. I'm not an Apple user and wanted to use it to instead charge two Android devices.The good news is both my Nexus 7 2013 and my Galaxy Note 2 recognize this as an AC Charger on either port used! In the status it says Charging (AC). Excellent! It's also very small which is nice.EDIT: Just got back from a week long road trip using my Nexus 7 as a GPS and unfortunately the tablet will lose battery charge even when plugged into this charger. I tried both ports and got the same result, but one may have discharged slightly faster. It discharges quite slowly and could last a whole day of driving but it would be empty at the end. It IS possible that the USB connection can not supply as much current as the tablet uses while navigating and that it isn't this charger's fault but I never tried plugging the tablet in using its AC adapter and my power inverter. Would be a good test to run.

reviewText: Before owning this dual socket USB charger, I owned/tested five other car chargers. The first thing that struck me about the design and manufacturing is how extremely tight the fit was compared to the others models tested.  The metal scraping and plastic crunching is a bit disconcerting. Secondly, for whatever reason, it charges my Galaxy Note II smartphone (i.e. phablet) slower than my OEM wall charger. I have seen this before with other high amperage wall and car chargers that should have no problem providing the necessary current. Hence, this might be some subtle circuitry issue particular to Samsung and/or this particular phone.That being said, Samsung might have a special way to impede non-oem charging that yet been reverse engineered. If anything, Anker and its competitors should try to understand what causes the slow charging.

reviewText: Our daughter needs a plug to keep her Kindle Fire charged in the back when playing battery draining games like Minecraft, watching movies or (gasp) reading. My wife needs a plug to keep her phone charged in the front on long road trips (or even around town). Our car only has one 12v socket in the dashboard Not a problem! This charger solves that problem perfectly. Although it says "Apple" and "Android" on the plugs, you can use either for either.There is no LED to let you know it's got power, so be aware of that.Be aware that this adapter doesn't include cables, it is just the adapter. Be sure to order your correct cables separately. I ordered the Mediabridge USB 2.0 high-speed cables for our Android phones and tablets, but any cable that's long enough will work. Their 6 foot cable works perfectly to provide a power cable to the back seat from the front seat plug, without having to be pulled tight.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: I like this model for car charging in rental cars with co workers...  I can full speed charge my android phone (Nexus 5) or tablet (Nexus 7), at the same time a co-worker full speed charges their iphone, or low speed (up to .5A) charges any other device.Note on charging...  Screen on, and smart phone GPS active uses a lot of power, a 500mah (.5A) charge rate will just /slow/ discharging, but wont maintain or charge the phone at the same time.  So make sure you use the correct port for your phone type/use.  A work around example for android devices...  If your Android phone works as an AP, and you have a tablet, you can put your phone on A (apple) port, and with the screen off, even sharing data by acting as an access point, it will have enough power to charge, then you can run your Android tablet (NA port) for nav, with screen on, and it will be able to do that and charge at the same time.  (yes it will charge slower than it would powered off, or with the screen off, etc, but it can do screen+nav+charge on the 'proper' port for the device type).
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: This product looks great. Over all impressive design and color. In past sometimes I used to forget to charge my ipod/iphone (which I use it to listen to music in car). Now I do not worry about that anymore. Also, I use my phone a lot so it is a great gadget to keep my phone charged without worrying about phone dying on you.I haven't used any other product like this before. Granted I use this in a hidden spot now and never unplug it.  So for me I do not have to wrap it in duck tape to keep it plugged in. His commute is fairly short, so he uses it to top off his phone battery generally and it's been working very well for that.[The product reviewed was provided to me at no cost for the purposes of review. reviewText: I've owned big, honking, ridiculous car charges. They stick out like the biggest, hairiest wart you can imagine and depending on what car I'm driving, actually got in the way with the gear changes.The Anker charger will charge any USB charging device. If you use Apple devices, use the port labeled Apple for more efficient and effective charging. If you use an Android device, use the Android port. If you use a Blackberry, or pretty much any other USB charge device, it seems to charge from either port just fine.The best feature is no indicator as to whether the charger is doing anything. Other chargers I've had had red lights, blue lights and green lights that lit the cabin of the car like Christmas. This doesn't light anything up, so charging my phone is simple and doesn't distract me while I drive.Highly recommended if you're in the market for a charger, not just one that is built to do Apple and Android charging.

title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: Since there are so many cheap USB adapters out there, I really hesitated to spend a few extra bucks to get these.  After they arrived I was very glad that I did!  I have been using these now for about two weeks and they are the best chargers for our Android and Apple cell phones that I have ever owned.  I have a habit of buying cheap stuff, and so I have probably gone through about 2 dozen phone chargers in the last 2-3 years.  They work for awhile and then I through them away and buy a few more.  I don't think that will be my experience with these Anker devices.  The fit and finish is excellent and they really feel like quality stuff -- but the real confirmation is when you put them to use.  I have found that they easily charge our cell phones in less than half of the time that the factory and other cheap chargers take.  Especially helpful in the car when you are only taking a 20 minute drive someplace and your phone is dead.  With my existing (cheap) chargers I would maybe get a 5 or 6% charge, but with these Anker devices I can easily see a 30-40% charge in the same amount of time!  Very happy that I purchased these -- I won't be going back to the cheap junk!
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: I upgraded from a less-smart Mediabridge charger, hoping to benefit from two full-power outlets and the smart Apple/Android switching.  It does work well at that.My problem is that it works itself loose in the socket and disconnects from power.Because it doesn't have a power LED (!), there's no way to know it disconnected until you see your phone running low.It also protrudes quite a bit from the DC Socket, so with the USB cable, it sticks out quite a ways onto your stickshift or parking brake. Really, this should have been more compact, or had the USB sockets on the side for versatile angles.So the circuitry seems good, but the form factor and fit are lacking.EDIT: After I was contacted by Anker, they replaced the unit with a new one.  The replacement charger fits the socket correctly, and has not worked loose.  It charges quickly and reliably, so I'm updating this review and increasing the rating.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: This product is simple, but does exactly what it sets out to do: outputs up to 3.6A of simultaneous power through its two USB ports. The port labeled "Apple" outputs 2.1A, which is sufficient to charge my iPad 2, Nexus 7, and Samsung Galaxy Note 2 at full speed. Also, no problems charging my wife's iPhone. Note that even though it is labeled "Apple," I've found that it works fine on all my devices. The other outputs 1.5A, which will still charge my Nexus 7 and Note 2, albeit slightly slower than intended. I've also tried plugging two devices in at once, and had no problems doing so. The charger itself fits snugly and has a nice, understated design, which I appreciate.My only gripe is that when I purchased it, it was only available in white. Had it been available in black, I would have definitely purchased the black version to better match my car interior and all my devices.Overall, I'm very pleased with this product. I have also purchased the 3.6A dual port home charger, which I'm equally happy with.If you're looking for nice quality cables to use with this charger (or any charger, for that matter), be sure to check out the Monoprice Premium USB to Micro USB Charge & Sync Cable. It comes in either black or white, and in 3ft and 6ft options. Very inexpensive.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: Anker is well known for it back up battery chargers for digital devices. But they have just come out with a new dual port car charger. It is calibrated for both Apple and Android products given that they use different voltages.One port is for Android devices and out puts 5 volts at 2.1 amps. The other port is for IOS devices and puts out 5 volts at 2.1 amps. The charger is 18 watts at 3.6 amps. It's a turbo charger to boot, which means that your devices will get filled up faster.You are going to have to use your own USB cables, but that shouldn't be a problem. This is a great solution if you have both Apple and Android devices, or it you have passengers with a different operating system than you use.If you are looking for a car charger, Anker has the answer in this sleek model. It comes in white and costs just $9.99. You can easily spend twice as much on a charger with half the functionality.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: I got this car charger to use mainly for charging up my Note 2 in the car, and from my own personal experience I use Note 2 every day as GPS to/from work. Everything is usually on (display, bluetooth), plus GPS/Google maps are up, and I take/make phone calls in a middle of all that. What does that mean? Battery is draining really fast, and even with car charger you need at least 2A output to be able to charge at faster rate than discharging with everything on. 2A charger is not hard to find, although question always come up if you can trust their actual rating. If you want to take it to the next level and charge another smart phone, you can probably find a dual charger with 2A and 1A, although reliability and current sharing during simultaneous use of ports might be in question. This new product from Anker took it to the next level where they are offering dual port output with 2.1A and 1.5A outputs and guarantee full current supply from each port at the same time. In terms of reliability, they are offering 18 months warranty which I think is a bold statement of confidence in their product.3.6A, which is 18W, is a lot of power and to my surprise the charger was actually very small and lightweight. The dimensions of the end with dual ports is only 26 mm x 24 mm, and the whole charger is very lightweight and only 22g. This small size is very convenient for tight spaces like in your arm-rest compartment, and just in general is unobtrusive to use anywhere in the car. I know they advertise it as dual port with 2.1A for Apple (obviously iPad) and 1.5A for smart phones, but I confirmed that Note 2 charges perfectly from Apple port. As a matter of fact that would be the best port to use for Note 2 fast charging.Overall it's a great little dual usb port car charger from a trusted company with a punch of 3.6A capacity split between 2.1A and 1.5A ports where both can be used simultaneously so you can do a fast charging of two devices at the same time. Plus you can't beat the price, a real bargain for a brand name quality product!
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: This is my second and it works perfectly.  The first was broken and returned (Anker seems to have a bit of a quality control problem, but they are very good at fixing things)  It will charge two 2A devices at the same time.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: One port for the I phone and one for the droid.  The Droid needs that extra boost and this delivers.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: Anker is making strides in making quality cell phone accessories.  The car charger is well built and is expected to last for a long time, I wish it came in black though.  I am glad that there's no blinding bright LED, I have another charger that does and it's annoying to drive at night and I also think it's a beacon for car thieves.  There are still minor flaws with the Anker car charger however.First is that the Apple and Android label is printed upside down!  Usually when a USB cable is plugged into a port, the pins would be on the bottom half and the USB port pins are on the top half.  It really bugs me but it doesn't affect functionality.Second is that I did not get a good fit when plugging the charger into my car's cigarette lighter.  There would be no conduction and it wasn't charging so I thought I got a bad unit initially.  I had to jam it in real good for it to work.  It could be my car's fault but I had other USB chargers that fit just fine.Lastly, the charger sticks out like a sore thumb compared to other chargers I've seen that are smaller and nearly flush with the surface, but I can't fault Anker since theirs are capable of charging power hungry tablets which likely requires more hardware to do so.Besides the nit picking, this is a fine quality made charger and would recommend it to those who needs a high amp charger for their tablets.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: I have been having a lot of problems in the last few months with car chargers and my various mobile devices.  I have been using an ipod touch, a Galaxy Nexus, a Galaxy S4, and a Galaxy tab--along with a Galaxy S3 and an iphone at various times.  I was having a real problem getting devices to consistently charge in the car--especially the Android devices that I would use as a GPS.The charger would not charge or keep up with the battery usage.  I would plug my phone in at the beginning of my trip, and after a couple of hours using it as a GPS I would discover my phone battery went down drastically--as if it did not charge at all.I then proceeded to try various different car chargers I have used in the past, with mixed results.  One day it would work, another day it would fail.  I also bought a bunch of new branded ones that claim to output a total of 3 or 4A output, but in practice they would not charge when I plugged two devices in at the same time (Android phone and ipod touch).I was ready to give up, when I came across this Anker product.  Based on other user reviews, I thought I would give it one last try.  To my great relief, this one actually does charge my devices--as promised.  Thank you!

reviewText: I already have several dual port chargers for my car, and I bought them because they were cheap enough when on sale. But they were cheap for a reason. In retrospect, if you take away the criterion that it has to work, I could have paid even less. So this time I wanted to go for something with quality from a manufacturer whose products I already trust.It would seem as if getting five volts out of a 12 volt car battery would be simple enough. But most chargers simply don't supply enough current. They are often only 500mA, while this one gives you 3.6A. That's enough to actually charge an iPad, while with other chargers, you might be able to maintain (or charge very slowly) your battery level in your phone and possibly slow down how fast your iPad drains its battery. This device will charge as fast as Apple's wall charger.This has the appearance of a high quality product. It doesn't look like something thrown in as a device accessory. It lacks an LED, which the manufacturer thinks adds to the elegance. My initial thought was that I rely on the LED to know when the device is working. But it may be that I needed it because other power supplies/chargers didn't work reliably. Since the devices themselves let you know when they are charging, I should have no problem without the LED.This one costs more. But you get what you pay for. I've probably spent more on other chargers that ended up in the e-waste bin.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: The charger was delivered with a few items I purchased (car charger, wall charger, and a portable battery pack).It's a little long, but clearly well built. Other chargers that feel like they're empty. When you pick this up, you can feel the difference.After a handfull of "cheap" chargers from the drug store, auto supply retailers, and online failed and needed replacing, I decided to do some research. I thought there had to be a better quality device than these cheap $5-$10 chargers. I found it - the Anker.I used to drive from LA to Phoenix with my phone on navigation and Pandora simultaneously and the battery would run down. Now with my Samsung Galaxy Note 3 the old chargers couldn't keep up at all and I would have to shut off my phone for a while and let it just charge.Enter the Anker. I now can drive taking calls with the phone while on Nav and Pandora and can also leave the screen on full bright and the battery never falls off of 100%. It even charges it up from nearly dead to 100% prety quickly while using whatever I need to use on the phone. There is plenty of power here and I couldn't be happier. I also suspect this charger will last me a long time.

reviewText: Ordered two chargers, and they were great at beginning with superb charging speed (displayed as AC) on Android phones. In less than a week one turned to USB charging type, soon started to stop charging intermittently. Switching back to older charger which stays charging to make sure the phone/cable are fine. Next day the 2nd charger started to behave same, i.e. slower charging, then stop charging intermittently.Both are on the way back to Amazon as there is no replacement option for 3rd vendor. May try again later... or not.Update 7/8: Received an email immediately from Anker offerring assistant. They believe the charger was defective and sent me two new units right away free of charge. Great customer service and looking forward to testing the new chargers.Update 7/22: I have used both new chargers for two weeks and found some more interesting facts. They work sometime as USB sometime as AC charging. I eventually figured out that during a hot day (here is very hot during summer, 3 digit temperature) if parked car outside for long time period the chargers will act as USB charging. But as soom as the temperature inside the car comes back normal the AC charging mode is delivered. I'm more suprised that the vendor just sent me another follow-up email asking about how the new units have been doing. I'm very happy with this purchase and will definitely buy again from them. I've owned various other Anker products (external battery backup chargers) and never had trouble with any of them. This is the first time I experience issue but their customer service from this vendor is unbelievablly amazing.

reviewText: Both the Samsung Droid Charge SCH-i510 and the Apple iPhone use 2.1 amps to fully charge. The Anker 18W / 3.6A Car Charger can output enough juice to charge *one* of these devices but not both. Know that you cannot charge two full featured phones that are in heavy use at the same time on this device. However, this will do fine if one phone is idle or off while the other phone is in use. That said, I prefer my dedicated 3 amp charger for my SCH-i510 device and use this on a second power port for other devices along for the ride, charging an iPod and a digital camera with this device. This is not an all-in-one solution sadly.
title: Anker® 24W Dual-Port Rapid USB Car Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air, mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8) and More (White)

reviewText: Got a chance to take this baby on its first field test last weekend.  We were out on a nice sunny day, and had been off-roading the day before to a remote lakeside beach.  Most everyone's phones were dead from trying to use GPS, so I brought this panel out to test it's abilities.  I laid it flat across my ARB awning, attached my friend's iPhone, put the iPhone in the attached velcro pouch, and let it charge.  The phone pouch hung perfectly down to the side of the awning so it wasn't in direct sunlight.Well, on a clear sunny day this fully charged his dead iPhone 5 in 1:45.  We couldn't believe it.  Faster than his home charger, he claims.  So, I put my Droid on there and took it from 34% to full in less than 2 hours as well.Not only did it charge faster than any of us expected, it's built well.  The grommets on the corners are solid, and the material feels like canvas.  It folds up compact to the size of my travel notebook, just smaller than an 8.5"x11" sheet of paper and it's less than 1" thick folded closed.  For what it does for its size, it's an asset I'm happy to carry.Needless to say I'm highly impressed with this panel.  Obviously we need a clear sunny day to get this kind of performance but I'm very encouraged by how well it did.  This panel will be in my backpack and camp gear on every trip from now on.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: I was skeptical, especially after a bad solar panel charger from another company but this works well. interestingly, my phone seems to charge a LOT faster with this than in a regular AC wall outlet. Put your phone inside a good quality oven mit (and another over mit on top) to prevent the phone or battery from overheating while charging.

reviewText: Update: Anker was kind enough to contact me and offer to replace my product. They sent me free shipping to return the old one and will ship me another one. Great!Original Review:This is a great design using quality, durable material to hold the panels. I love how it folds up and has build-in metal-ringed holes for hanging it! It's the perfect size for putting on your dashboard in your car to charge devices while driving.It worked great for the first few months. Now it just doesn't seem to work all the time. It still works, but it's not reliable with my cell phone. Sometimes it works and other times it doesn't seem to be putting out electricity at all. When it does work, sometimes the charge is so small (in direct sunlight) that the phone has to be OFF to recognize that it is getting electricity. I have checked the cords and made sure that it is plugged snugly into the USB 1 output slot on the solar charger.I'm not sure if I got a defective one, or maybe if it's my phone but this hasn't worked quite as well as I had hoped.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

Clean energy when you need it.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: I’ve had my Anker 14 watt solar charger for a couple of weeks now.The Anker solar charger cells are rated at 14 watts, and as Anker states, the unit produces 5 V with 2 amps max, or 10 watts under assumingly IDEAL conditions.  Apparently 4 of the listed 14 watts are lost via internal wiring and circuit board configuration.Thus for practical purposes, under a bright sunny sky with no cloud cover at all, the 10 watt realistically probably produces 6-8 watts, settling at 7 watts +/-.These probable 7 watts at 5V will produce 1.4 amps.When I use my Cooper 120V wall outlet charger, 5V at .7 amps (700mA) it charges my Lumia 925 battery (2000 mAh) at the rate of 6% for every 10 minutes, or an output of 3.5 watts.Extrapolating; The Cooper’s 3.5 watts charges the Lumia 925 at a 6% increase every ten minutes.  Thus, the Anker’s 7 watts should charge the Lumia 925 at twice the rate in a bright sunny sky.  7watts/3.5 watts = twice the rate.So, with the Anker, the Lumia 925’s battery rate will increase by 12% every 10 minutes under full sun.  Example – a 50% battery should be fully charged in just over 40 minutes.In all tests, the Anker was hung vertically, or, laid flat on a table.  I did not angle to the sun, nor rotate with the sun.  That would be too tedious.In a nut shell, when charging my Lumia 925 (2000mAh) I have found that for every 10 minutes:1.  In full outdoor sun there was a 10% increase in battery life.  Close to my aboveestimate, and better than the Cooper.2.  In full outdoor sun to haze a 7% increase.  Just about he same as the Cooper.3.  With a hazy sun to partly cloudy 4% was achieved.4.  Outdoors and indoors in the shade produced little or negligible results.5.  Hung on an east facing full sun storm door with a screen produced 3%.6.  Placed on a sill between the screen and glass of a west facing window 3.8%7.  Placed against UV tinted windows – ZERO.Actual test results:My first actual test was outdoors in full sun for only ten minutes with my Lumia 925.  The Anker panel was place flat on a table for 10 minutes and the battery rise went from 83% charged to 93% charged.  A 10% increase, for an output of 5.8 watts for the 10 minutes (again, extrapolating with the 3.5W at 6% via the Cooper) on the Anker.  Pleasing.My next test was a few hours later with a partial cloud cover (50%).  The Anker was again placed flat on a table outdoors.  My Lumia battery was at 84%.  With a check every 10 minutes, the battery took 40 minutes to reach 100%.  The average rate of charge for each ten minutes was 4%.  Again, extrapolating with the Cooper, the production rate on the Anker with partial cloud cover was 2.3 watts.  Acceptable.With a full to hazy sun, the Lumia went from 83% to 90% in ten minutes.  This was a gain of 7% or a production of 4 watts.With the Anker outdoors, placed flat in the shade on a full sun day, the Lumia went from 44% charged to 49% charged in 50 minutes. An average increase of 2.5% every 10 minutes to the battery.  A charging rate of 1.5 watts every 10 minutes.  Not too great.The Anker was then hung vertically on an east facing storm door window (not tinted) that has a fine mesh screen.  In the shade on a full sun day, the Anker did not produce a charge.  It seems that being in the shade and the screen hampered charging.  Drats!With the Anker on the same storm door window (not tinted) that has a fine mesh screen.  In a full sun, through the screen, in 45 minutes, I had a battery rise of 13%, or 3% every 10 minutes, for a production of 1.75 watts every 10 minutes.  Somewhat acceptable.On a clear day, with full sun, I put the Anker on an indoor tinted window (all the windows in my house are UV tinted).  Zero charge.  I read that tinted windows will let a solar charger function to a degree.  With my tinted windows, there was NO charging.  Drats!I opened the west facing tinted window and placed the Anker against the fine mesh screen. I draped the USB cord on the sill and lowered the window back down carefully to close the window.  Inside, I placed the micro-USB in the Lumia.  With a full sun and some haze, in a 2.5 hour test, checking periodically, the Lumia battery went from a 42% charge to 100% in the 2.5 hours.  This worked out to an average 3.8% rise every 10 minutes, for an average production of 2.2 watts every 10 minutes.  This is acceptable as it is easy to set up here and the sun lasts at this window for four hours.I then tried my tablet with its huge 9000mAh battery.  Since my Lumia battery is 2000mAh it should take 4.5 times a long to obtain similar charging results.In a full to hazy outdoor sun, the tablet’s battery went from 85% to 100% in 1 hour and 20 minutes.  A 15% gain, which translates to a 1.8% gain every 10 minutes.If you multiply this 1.8% gain by 4.5, the 8% resultant is very close to the actual 7% gain of the Lumia in a similar outdoor condition.I am more than pleased with the results and potential of this Anker 14 watt panel.I hope I didn’t bore too many people with this drawn out review.  If I did, I apologize.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology
