reviewText: This thing is awesome and was a bargain when amazon had it for $59.99. I use it for hiking and charging an Anker 10,000MAh pack  during the day so i can power my tech toys at night (music mostly)  works like a champ. I came back to buy another one, but now that they raised the price $10 i find myself looking at the instapark mercury27 that seems to offer a lot more for (now) not a lot more money.  I can say I planned to buy 2 more but probably wont.  its a good product, well more of a toy, but not worth $75 after tax.  I'd give it 5 stars if the seller hadnt priced it out of it's market and into that of somewhat better panels with 12v capabilities.performance wise?  its charged everything I've tried - and quickly - then again I live in southern california and sun isnt exactly hard to come by over here.  quality?  great build - build solid and folds up compact. no issues with any of the connections yet 6 months in.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: At first, I had my doubts, since this is my first Anker product, and especially with previous experiences on other solar chargers. Have bought few ones in the past, who use to charge, for example, a 3.000 mAh external battery, in almost 10 hours of full sunlight exposure, which is a lot of time.But this one exceeded all my expectations. It's amazing 2+ Amps of current for real! I've tested charging my Galaxy Note 3, from 20% of battey. Half hour later, it was in almost 40%! And my phone wasn't even in airplane mode, so everything was working during the charge. So it would probably charge up to 100% in less than 2 hours, which is extremely fast.Made with very quality materials. It looks that it could work in medium to hard conditions. Very well made. The size, when folded, is very like a 10.1 tablet, and could fit in any regular size backpack.Love this product! And from now one, i'll be having Anker as my first choice, for every other product. Totally recommend it.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: I used this with the Anker battery when out the field. I can leave this on top of the car or truck to keep the battery charged or to charge my phone. Works great, and is nice and tough, and rugged.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: This panel goes on sale somewhat often for around $50 or less, and I would wait for then to buy it if possible.However, even at the regular price, this is a great product, at least for my uses. It can handily recharge pretty much anything you'd want charged via USB (you'll get 10W or more in even moderately decent light), it's durable, and it folds up nicely.I use mine to charge devices like my Bluetooth headset while I'm at work by leaving this on my dash and plugging in the headset. Once summer rolls around, I might reconsider, but it works great for me for now. Also, as a test, on a longish commute home, it managed to bring a Kindle Fire HDX 7" from nearly dead to almost charged, so that's a good sign as well.This would make a great camping companion if you have one or two devices you need charged but don't want to carry extra batteries - or you could hang it off your pack, charge an external as you hike, and use that to charge your devices at night.Also, *unlike* the Goal Zero system I bought earlier, this does *not* come with a strong chemical smell. It was essentially odorless right out of the box. The Goal Zero *still* stinks, although less nauseatingly so after a few months.Strongly recommended. I've not used any of their other solar products, but I'm inclined to try them now.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: this is by far the best and easiest to use solar chargers I have come across. its built well and looks like it will last a good few years the ports are fastened solid and it charges my samsung galaxy s4 easily even when not in direct sunlight. for the price it is a unbeatable value. I have a Goal zero solar panel pack as well and it was double the price and not even half the power output.this is a awesome item to have and in a extended power outage or a camping trip this will make a world of difference
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: This was the first product by Anker that I had purchased, and I am very satisfied with it.  It is well made from quality components, and a great value when compared to similar products from other companies.Anker claims that this unit outputs 14 watts.  I used a multimeter to test the output from it's USB ports.  Under bright mid afternoon sunlight with the panel facing directly toward the sun, I measured approximately 5.3 volts and ~2.7 amps, which = 14.31 watts.  Your results may vary depending on location and weather, but I believe that in this product, Anker is currently offering one of the better portable solar panels for the price.After my experience with this, I decided to purchase an Anker battery pack charger to use in conjunction with this solar panel to charge my electronic devices during emergencies, and am completely satisfied with the quality and operation of that unit, too.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: Consider this one of my best purchase last year, it charges my easyac battery pack.A little awkward to set up, I had to use 550 cord and some creative lashing to get it set in the right place.Folds up well, very well built.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: So far so good - I have tested it from a bay window and it works ok. I believe in Anker and their products and as soon as there is more reliable "sun" then I will update my review. Product seems to work as long as mother nature works.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: I have owned three portable solar chargers none worked very well,  It seems to me the problem is the number of panels installed on the charger along with total wattage, the less solar panels and wattage the longer it will take to get a full charge on your mobile device. The Anker 14W Solar Panel Charger actually works! and might I say works quite well! With four large panels at 14 Watt's it chargers amazingly quick, for example I had a battery pack at only 20% capacity, connected the Anker Panel (using usb) to my battery pack and placed them on the dashboard of my car, I usually drive two and a half hours a day in sunny California, within five days my battery pack  was at 95% capacity!. I highly recommend this Solar Panel (by the way it also folds up and has a side pouch to protect your battery pack or mobile device from the sun when charging).P.S. Keep in mind that the rate of charge depends on the amount of sun your panel is exposed to, if partly cloudy it will naturally take longer to get a full charge.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: Another hit from Anker.  Impressive build quality and does what  it says on the box.  Tried it on my Note 3  and it worked flawlessly. If you ever needed a charger on the go outdoors and power wasn't available this is what you need.  If you want you could also use it as an alternative if you want to be pro green.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: Do you need something to charge your phone on a hiking trip? Well this might just be that device for you. The charger is really light so if you have it in a backpack your won’t even notice you have it. It has a nice big pocket inside for you to keep your charging cable in it. The design of the product is really nice. It looks like it can take some drop damage. The only major issues That I have came across is that it sometimes won’t charge your device. Like on an iPhone it comes up with the message that this accessory isn’t compatible to charge. The only way I have found to fix that issues is to unplug the device from the charger and plug it in again after that it seems to work just fine.  It charges your device rather slowly which is understandable since its using the sun to charge. Overall this product is a really neat product.  I would recommend this product to anyone that like to get out and spend a lot of time outside."I was provided with a free copy of this item for testing and my fair and honest evaluation”
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: I am not sure why I didn't order this a long time ago. It worked really well. I do need to try charging two devices at once but I had my iPhone 5S plugged in and charging by the hotel pool last weekend. Definitely useful for boating, beach or camping. Well built and fairly light. You can store wires in the pouch where the USB connections are.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: This thing works really well for me when charging my iPhone but I have not been able to get it to charge my iPad, even in full, no-clouds, midday sun. I bought it for a camping trip and I look forward to using it but I'm glad I tested it first.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: As more a test than anything, I've tried using this panel to completely charge my phone and my portable USB battery packs. I park my car with panel in dash facing most daytime sun while charging external solar battery power pack. At night I charge my phone from battery pack, and repeat process next day. I get charging even on cloudy days, albeit much slower but still enough that through my month long testing I've never had to shut off phone due to lack of solar power!I love this item and have already purchased more as gifts for family - who also love them!
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: I have had this solar charger for around a week now, which has given me time to thoroughly test it.  I am very impressed with its performance.Test One:  iPhone 5C Charge from 0% to 100%:On my first test, I totally discharged the battery on an iPhone 5C by running the flashlight until the battery was completely drained.  The next morning at 9AM, I connected the iphone to the solar charger.  The screen indicated the phone was charging.  I placed the solar charger on the rail of my deck - and at that time, it was sunny out but the sun was obscured by a large oak tree on the edge of my property, so the solar charger was not in direct sunlight.I checked it again at 1PM (4 hours later), and the battery was at 41% charged (as indicated by the iPhone's display).  It was mostly sunny that day - and at some points, the sun was obscured by clouds - although at around 10:30AM, the trees no longer obscured the sun from the solar charger.At 4:30PM (7.5 hours of charging), the battery was at 82%.  When I checked it this time, I noticed a message on the iPhone's display which read "This accessory may not be supported."  I saw that the little lightning bolt charge indicator was also not on, so I disconnected and reconnected the charger.  The lightning bolt charge indicator came on again.  Based on my experience - and in other things I have read, this message appears if the solar charger is producing a low amount of current (when obscured by clouds, etc.) - however, charging continues during these periods of time although at a lower rate.I checked it again at 5:30PM and the iPhone had 100% displayed for the battery level.  So within 1 hour, it went from 82% to 100% (during a period of the day when it was clear and sunny).  I am extremely pleased with these results.Test Two:  Charging the Anker 10000mah External Battery PackI bought the "Anker 2nd Gen Astro E3 10000mAh with PowerIQ(tm) Technology" external battery pack from Amazon at the same time I purchased this solar charger.  I paid $29.99.  Link is:http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009USAJCC/ref=oh_details_o02_s00_i01?ie=UTF8&psc;=1I totally charged the battery pack, then used it to charge some devices until the battery pack was totally discharged.  I then connected it to the solar charger the next morning at 8:30AM and left it plugged in the entire day.  I checked it periodically throughout the day.  The day was very sunny, although there were some intermittent clouds - but very few.  It took around 4 hours to go from 0% to the 25% mark (as indicated by one of the 4 LEDs remaining steadily lit.  I left it plugged in the full day until well after dark.  When I checked it after arriving home late, the 3rd LED was blinking and 2 of the 4 LEDs were steady.  This indicates that the battery pack was between 50 - 75% charged.I plugged it up again the next morning at 9AM.  When I checked it again at 1:15PM, the battery pack was totally charged.  I unplugged it and plugged it back in to confirm.  I am also extremely satisfied with these results.  This battery, at 10000mah, holds a lot of charging potential.  I can charge an iphone at least 3-4 times and and ipad with it as well.I also bought a little USB fan from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003XN24GY/ref=oh_details_o02_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc;=1).  When I plug this up to the ANKER solar charger, if it outside during the day (even in the shade), the USB fan will run uninterrupted.I almost bought the 14W Anker Solar Charger instead of the 8W one, but after these tests I am convinced that this 8W unit more than fulfills my needs.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: I have used this item every chance I have so my car battery does not get abused and drained from all my devices that need charging
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: Charges at advertised amps under full sunlight.  I have no issues charging a iPod mini retina or iPhone 5s under full sunlight.  It will also charge a Ankers  2 Gen Astro3 12000 mAh, albeit every slowly. The key to faster charging is full sunlight on a clear day.  I use this primarily on a car fat the beach or on a boat in direct sunlight.  It packs small and is relatively lite.  Construction is very solid.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: I've said it before, and I'll say it again...I love Anker products.  I bought this Solar Panel for when we go camping.  Of course, it will be great if we have a power outage on a sunny day.  Then again, I live in WNY.  During the winter, we don't get much sun.  As an example:  I bought this quite a while ago, and have only just now had a chance to test it out.  This was a much longer winter than usual.I finally tested this with my Anker 2nd Generation External Battery.  The day was kind of hazy.  Not really cloudy, but not really bright in the sunshine department.  This Solar Panel was able to charge the battery about 10% in an hour.  That is pretty good under the conditions.  I'm sure it will charge much faster on a bright, sunshiny day.It doesn't weigh much, and folds up pretty flat.  I keep it in a basket with all my "travel electronics".  It hardly takes up any room at all.If you are going to be "Off the Grid" for any length of time, (camping, hiking, biking, etc.) this is a great idea.  As long as there is sunshine, you will have power.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: I've used this product a few times so far, and been pleased with it.  It seems sturdy and has charged both my iPad Mini and iPhone 5s almost as fast as if they were plugged in to the wall.  I find it works fine when laid flat in sunshine, charging with no problem.  I tried leaning it up at a bit of an angle against a picture window...there it was a bit touchier.  It did fine on the iPhone, but wanted the sun to be full on it (no overcast clouds) to maintain a steady charge for the iPad.  I'd hear a faint beep and find a message on the screen warning me that not all connections could charge an iPad...but when the sun came back out full, it did fine.  Essentially it seems that for the iPad, overcast days and/or the angle of the charger makes a difference...which I'd expect, since it requires more power.  The next day, outside with the charger laid flat, it did a super job.I'm very pleased with Anker products...I own about 5 items or more, and every one has worked as expected or better.  I don't think you'll go wrong with this, and I like the idea that I can charge my Anker backup battery chargers with the solar charger during the daytime and have enough power to go through the night and then some.  (Or have power if the next day is cloudy.)  Thanks, Anker!
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: Anker is known for making very high quality products at a great price, and this solar charger is no exception. On sunny days this thing works FAST! Will charge your electronic devices on the go for free. Can't beat that. Get one now before the S*&T hits the fan.

reviewText: I have used this while fishing and it works great. I charged my phone and my portable backup charger. It will come in handy during a power outage or camping trip.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: My obsession with external batteries started a couple of years ago after a few nasty storms we went through here on East Coast. Nothing is worse than loosing power for a week or more and figuring out how to charge your phone. Around that time, I was thinking how great it would have been to have a solar panel.  Looking around for available choices, I was pleased to see 14W foldable dual-port model from Anker.I was pleased to see that no matter how big or small a product Anker sells, it still arrives in an environmentally friendly packaging. Once you take it out of the box, you can really feel it's hefty weight, almost 1.7lb. Unfolding the charger revealed 4 solar panels, each one about 6" x 9". Everything was packaged inside of foldable rugged construction made out of heavy polyester canvas material. The solar panels were not removable and stored inside of individual pockets covered by heavy duty clear PET plastic screen material. A lot of thought went into the design to make sure the construction is durable for outdoor use and the front of the panel, which supposed to be exposed to a sun, will remain undamaged in direct heat. As a matter of fact, once you unfold this solar charger, you will find an extra fold with a dual output USB port and a velcro pocket where you can store your smartphone or external battery to keep it away from the direct heat. It actually came very handy when I left my phone outside charging and was able to keep it out of the direct sun light inside of this pocket.Without a doubt, this is a very compact foldable solar charger, but how does it perform in the sun? Unfortunately for a few days when I was testing it, I wasn't able to take advantage of a full direct sun (cloudy). From the spec of this charger, it can supply 5V with a combined 2A between both ports. It's definitely possible and I've read plenty of reviews with people who were able to get maximum charging speed. In my case, the first test didn't yield the greatest results because I was sitting in a shade and was only able to get 300-400 mA of charging current. The next day I was able to get better results with 800 mA of charging current, though it was still a bit cloudy outside. I'm pretty sure in a direct sunlight I will be able to get a much higher current reading. So my plan is to continue testing and posting my updates.Overall, this was my first Solar Charger experience, and I found it to be very impressive. Of course, the big limitation is finding a perfect sunny spot to take full advantage of maximum charging speed. But even if you are stuck in a shade or the sun is down already, you can still get enough charging current to boost your smartphone or tablet battery. With a very competitive pricing and backed up by 18-months warranty, this solar charger can come very handy in a lot of places where you're away from the power outlet.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: This charger was perfect for what I needed. It not only charged my iPhone while I was on my cross country bike ride, but it also powered my Garmin Nuvi GPS. At the end of my day, I would simply fold up the charger and put it away for the night, in the mornings I would put it back on my trailer, connect the wires, and I was on my way.I would recommend this product in a heartbeat !!!
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: This is the best direct-charge panel I've seen for anything near this price. It isn't the most lightweight or compact unit out there, but it's reasonable at both and does a very good job charging for the size. The panels are well protected and the package is built to last.The charger has two 2 Amp, 5V ports- however the total output is 2 Amps. So you can charge two devices at 1 Amp or one at 2. Aside from a few tablets, there's not many out there that can handle more than 2 anyway- most phones use 1 Amp input. The panel does not have a built-in battery, but you can just hook one up. I've used it with the Astro E5 and it works fine.I was able to charge a smartphone from dead to 100% in about 4.5 hours, with the panel unattended in somewhat direct sunlight on a partly cloudy day. The phone in question was a HTC One V with a 1,500 mAh battery. This is great performance, considerably better than several 7W panels I've tried. I should also note that this is able to charge anything I've thrown at it even on not particularly sunny days. That can be an issue for some smaller panels, as they simply don't have the power to charge certain devices. In fact, if it's a partly cloudy day some smaller panels can actually end up draining a device's battery- especially if it's a device that wakes the screen or shows something when it starts charging. Since the charge is more likely to be intermittent, dropping in and out of the necessary minimum voltage, it can repeatedly wake the device and actually kill the battery.The panel folds up into a roughly 8.5x11" package, about an inch thick. The dual charge ports are enclosed in a pocket large enough to hold most smartphones, with a velcro fastener. There's four metal holes for attachment, and the whole thing has a velcro flap to keep it wrapped up. The whole thing is wrapped in thick canvas. When fully unfolded, it's a pretty good size- about a yard long; you can choose to leave it partly folded and it'll work, but at less power. This is definitely more suitable for leaving out on a table or chair somewhere in the sun, not carrying strapped to your back or somesuch. It weighs a pretty good amount too, so I wouldn't use it for backpacking or other activities where space and weight are at a premium. However, it's plenty rugged and effective for a camping trip or emergency use. I'd even say that this is suitable for daily home or work use, as it can provide a significant boost to your smartphone or external battery pack within a reasonable time. I've found that smaller panels are usually not practical for this as you'd have to leave them out in the sun for hours on end to get any significant result, and due to their small size a slight change in weather or shadows can greatly impair their effectiveness.As with most panels, leaving it behind glass does impair the charge rate pretty heavily. Fortunately for this one, it's very well protected with hard, clear plastic on all the panels and will work fine outdoors. This protects them well against scratches and impact. The panels themselves appear to be weather resistant as described, though I doubt the charge ports are- it can probably hold up to some light rain since they're covered by the flap, but otherwise I wouldn't leave it out in inclement weather. Honestly though, as far as leaving it outside charging, I'd be more concerned about someone making off with it than the unit being damaged by the elements. If you can seal off the ports and whatever devices you have attached, I have no doubt that the panels will be able to take whatever nature can throw at them.This panel is worth the cost, for sure- it's better than some considerably more expensive ones on the market. It's a good compromise between power/function and portability. It isn't for every use scenario imaginable (nothing really is) but it works well for what I'd use it for (camping, topping off my phone at lunch, emergencies). The build quality is solid, and it charges things fast. Under ideal circumstances, it is actually as fast as a wall charger. Hard to beat.
title: Anker® 14W Dual-Port Portable Foldable Outdoor Solar Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology

reviewText: I insist on powerful chargers and my spouse just doesn't want anything heavy. This is the best of all worlds. One charger that can handle a briefcase full of phones and tablets -- and charge them very fast. I've tried the "official" chargers that come with the products, the (excellent value!) Monoprice 4-port chargers, and all manner of others from heavy hitters like Belkin all the way down to cheapo counterfeits. Many work very capably, but can only handle one tablet plus one phone, while a few can do two tablets. None can be loaded up like this baby from Anker, which can handle FOUR tablets and one phone. That's flat out awesome and, although the price is a bit steep at $25.99, it's cheaper than buying three Monoprice chargers, and the quality is top drawer. I like them so much that I'm buying two more to park around my home in place of the multi-charger mess I have now.

reviewText: Product worked fine for a while.  Loved the small size and convenience of being able to charge multiple USB devices simultaneously. But within the first month, two of the five ports stopped working. Other reviewers report similar problems, so it would seem there is a quality-control issue with this product, or the unit has a design flaw that makes it too delicate or too susceptible to failure.Anker offers an 18-month warranty, but for me the time and hassle involved in repackaging, making a special trip to the post office, etc., hardly seems worth the trouble for a product that only cost $25.  So I'll probably just keep it until the remaining three ports die, as well, and then buy something else.Update 07-21-2014: Anker emailed me directly after reading my negative review and offered to ship me a new unit at no cost and without having to return the old unit. They requested only that I provide the serial number of the defective unit. I accepted their offer and received the new unit within a week. It works fine and I'll keep my fingers crossed that it continues to do so. I'm upgrading my rating to 5 stars on account of the fact that I really like the product -- so long as it keeps working -- and I'm satisfied with Anker's fast and no-hassle replacement.
title: Anker® 40W 5-Port Family-Sized Desktop USB Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8); Nexus and More (Black)

reviewText: This transformed a little chunk of my life. I'm a technology worker/road warrior. I don't have a "desk" area I always return to, except for my night stand. So like a lot of night stands, it was a ridiculous mess of chargers. And I would often take those chargers (or one or two) with me in my bag in the morning. A lot of plugging, unplugging, a mess of cords, power strips, extension cords (ever try to plug in 4 or 5 chargers in one area?) - ugh.This replaces them all. Perfectly. No - better than replacing them. This charges anything. Fast. This has a single, neat, normal AC cord (no brick) that leads to a tiny little white (or black) box with USB connectors where you plug in 5 devices. It's much smaller than it looks in pictures. It replaces 5 chargers, and it doesn't get hot. How? Why it works so well and others don't - it's a mystery.I've bought Anker products for a couple of years now, and always thought well enough of them, but between this and their new Astro2 chargers - wow - I need to invest in this company. They will OWN the accessory market soon.With this - you can travel with ONE CHARGER! You AND your wife! You can go to a hotel and find just one lousy AC outlet, with no space for a brick charger/wall wort, and plug this in - the 5 foot cord (a detachable industry standard one, too!) is usually plenty long enough so you can charge and use your devices while lounging in bed.Here's what I charge with mine at home, often 4 or 5 of these simultaneously:1) 7 inch Nook Tablet that's always running as a video baby monitor (and it likes a 2 amp charger since it's always on)2) a Nook HD+ 9 inch tablet (this also uses a 2 amp charger, but when the screen is off it's far less demanding)3) A Samsung Galaxy Note 2 - also always on as a clock (and this really demands a 2 amp charger)4) A Plantronics Wireless Bluetooth Speakerphone5) A Plantronics Bluetooth headset (technically the charging case/battery for the Voyager Legend)6) An Anker 2nd Gen Astro2 9000mAh external battery chargerLike other Anker products of late, it comes packaged nicely with good quality instructions, and the device itself is rather stylish and feels like an extremely high quality unit. But even without some of that - it's still a must have.Seriously - this is one of those seemingly silly little quality of life enhancing items that once you have it - you're going to wonder how you lived without it - like a good remote control for a TV/DVR/AV receiver, or your first remote garage door opener.They're in and out of stock lately - a hot item (I had to get white, in fact, since black was out of stock), and for good reason. Buy it now! You can't afford to go another night with a deadly octopus of charger cords next to you while you're sleeping. (You know those things are getting closer and closer to killing you in the middle of the night, right?)
title: Anker® 40W 5-Port Family-Sized Desktop USB Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8); Nexus and More (Black)

reviewText: I just bought two of these chargers last week and had the chance to use them over the weekend. I'm very pleased. They do what they promised. Thanks to PowerIQ, they can charge any device on any port, rather than having to put Apple devices in some ports and Androids in others for best charging efficiency -- I've always felt I was getting only half the use out of those devices. My only wish for these batteries would be for the output to match the number of ports at full speed (2.4 * 5 = 12 amps out shared among the five ports), as the total amps shared by the three ports is 8.I have an app on my android tablet that tells me what my amps are coming in when I plug the device into a charger. When I've used ports that were designated for Apple, even though the port was rated at 2.1 to 2.4 amps, it would read lower coming in than the Android port that was was listed as 1.0 to 1.2 amps. With these chargers, I get the same amps reading on every port.
title: Anker® 40W 5-Port Family-Sized Desktop USB Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8); Nexus and More (Black)

reviewText: I have come across the Anker brand in recent months, and grew liking its product. So far, I have owned three different Anker product.This device stands out just by looking at it. The enclosure material (faux leather) feels sophisticated, not like some cheap plastics. It is well built with attention to detail. Even the packaging and manual are carefully designed, like what you would expect from something made by Apple. While I hate those clear plastic packaging when you have to rip the whole thing apart, unboxing this charger is a great experience in itself.I liked the concept of a multi-port charger that does not require users to know which port any particular devices are plugged into. The most common USB cable is about 3-ft. If you plug a bunch of them into a multi-port charger, you would have a hard time to tell which port is charging which device, unless if 1) you color coded the cable itself; or 2) there are individual LED indicators.The lack of LED light is a good thing, since most cheap devices have very bright LED lights, especially the blue kind, which has its own health risk. The concept of charging any ports you want is perfect, as it completely eliminates the need for LED light. One might argue that it might be helpful to have at least one LED lamp to indicate that the adapter is plugged into a power source, or additional lamp per port to indicating that the device is charging. But com'on, most device would have its own indicator that tells you whether it is in charging mode or not, so there really isn't a need for any LED lights on the adapter.I also purchased the Quirky Cordie cable organizer to compliment this charger, and it really work together.http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004GUS4XK/The cable organizer allows four cables to be firmly anchored (pun intended) together, so you don't have to mess with the entanglement of the mid-sections of multiple USB cables. I used this to secure all the cables into a manageable bundle.http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004MMEHKG/That allows one empty charging port from the charger that I can use for some ad hoc pieces, including a proprietary cable used by some weird bluetooth headset.Now, back to the charging capability. While all the discussion about IQ design and charging protocol intelligence sound interesting, whereas the talk about energy efficiency makes you feel good, I find most reviews lack substance. That is, how do we know for sure that it actually is performing better than other chargers.My experience tells me that it is not as good as it claims.To test my theory, I tested it against charging Nexus 5. I waited it for the device to discharge to 6% remaining power, and plugged in the charging cable. (No other ports were used for charging.) It took 2 hours 20 minutes to reach full charge. The starting and stopping timestamps were measured by an Android app called Battery Graph.In another word, this charger is 27% slower than the standalone ASUS charger!!!The second test uses the OEM charger that comes with a first gen Nexus 7 (2012). The ASUS adapter is the most capable standalone chargers in my possession, which delivers 2.0A. (I did not choose the LG charger that came with the Nexus 5 because its stated charging amperage is merely 1.2A.) Under the same charging condition, the charge took 1 hour 50 minutes.That means, the Anker 40W charger takes 30 minutes longer than the 2.0 standalone charger to fully recharge the device. That is disappointing.For my third and last test, I used a second gen Astro 3 12000mAh external battery, also manufactured by Anker. It took about 2 hours to charge from 6% to 90%. I didn't complete the test, since it is already surpassed the time the ASUS charger took for full charge. In that sense, both the Anker charger and the Anker external battery are charging at the same rate (a.k.a., both graph slopes are similar). Because they both claim to use the PowerIQ technology, I came away with the conclusion that this Anker charger (as well as the external battery) is as good as I could get from this design, so I am not inclined to return (or exchange) it for a better one.However, it is certainly not the fastest charger you can get. The full charging capacity you get from this particular charger is definitely less than the charging capacity that is allowed by the device itself (Nexus 5 in my example).While I'm keeping the multi-charger, I am not doing away with my ASUS charger any time soon. I used the ASUS charger for all my devices as much as I could before I had this Anker charger, and I would continue using that one.when you are going to buy this product, have an expectation that it is really not charging as fast as it can. And it could all come down to the (conservative) design born out of engineering.

reviewText: Anker  releases yet another over-priced over hyped mediocre product. Its not universal, it does not put more output than the Skiva 4A that costs half as much (and has adapters for everything). I charged Samsung Glaxy Tab, HP touchpad (which the Skiva charges but this does not), HTC One, Moto-X . The Skiva charged faster than this.The only advantage is the physical design which is better than Skiva (Skiva is way too bulky) .Update:Their customer service is amazing. reviewText: This is a no nonsense charger. Other chargers have specific ports for specific devices. To get the quickest and optimal charge, you must plug in the correct device to the corresponding port. The last such charger I had only has one iPhone port. The other ports are for iPad, Samsung Tab, etc. We have three iPhones in our house. We also have four different Bluetooth devices that need charging as well as a Verizon tablet. Granted, one could plug in your device into any of the dedicated ports, but charging will take longer.Enter the Anker with "PowerIQ Technology." You can plug any device into any port and it automatically detects the device's power requirements and gives it the quick, optimal charge! No worries. I like that.The Anker is a quality build and is compact for grabbing and go for trips. The price is right, so get one.

reviewText: This charger is a lifesaver. I have 2 now because of how great and fast it is.  If you have a lot of devices like me (Ipad 2 & 4, Iphone, Note 3, and Misc other USB devices) and need it charged quickly, this will do it for you.  I have not found any other usb charger on the market at this charging rate and at this quality for the price.  I can charge all 4 devices at almost max speed (~2.1amp) which is especially important for the new retina ipads that need a little longer charging time.  The cord length is perfect because not everyone can stay near a outlet.  This is a great product and it will not let you down (As with any anker product)Also, the Black color has a more matte black look and feel.  The white has a clear coat look and feel.  I have both and both are great either way.  I just feel that the black will not slip on any surface. So if you need the matte grip texture, get the black.

reviewText: As most devices these days come standard with charging cables that begin with a USB to attach to the charging unit that you plug in, you can ditch that part and just take this thing and plug up to 5 USB cables to it to charge your items.  I remember going to conventions back in the day and bringing a huge power strip that accommodated all the wall chargers for all my gadgets.  Now, I just bring the wires and I can charge both of my cell phones, my tablet, my mirrorless camera and my GPS unit.  The practicality of this thing should be quite obvious in that you can charge multiple devices that use a USB-based cord and it'll charge them at the recommended voltage as it can detect what the best possible charging output should be for each device.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: Power IQ works!! This is actually my second unit and it speaks volumes on how good this unit it. I have tried Bolse 4 port USB charger which at first I thought was neat. I also have the first generation Anker USB charger (not power IQ) that seems to be a hit and miss when I charge my Nokia Lumia 920 with it......I sometimes wake up on the morning with my nokia's battery totally drained  and the phone very hot using the older anker charger. It has not happened with the power IQ and I was so convinced I got a second unit for travel purposes. Using my Bolse travel charger, my iphone 5s touch screen gets so finicky when I am using it while being charged. This does not happen with the anker power IQ....this is to me the best there is. No need to see which port is for android, iOs or ipad.....because the charger will automatically determine the optimal charge for the unit being hooked with it......it is a trully plug and play charger......I love it!

reviewText: I had previously purchased the 25W white model, but since I needed an extra one this one looked like the one to get. The biggest surprise when I received it was how much smaller it is compared to the older 25W model.A huge benefit is that this new model does not have specific high power tablet ports: you can plug in these devices in any port as long as the total power drain remains below the total 40W capacity. Since I don't own four iPads, I wasn't able to test what happens when you exceed the capacity; this product is actually capable of charging four iPads simultaneously at full speed, or three iPads and two iPhones. This doesn't seem like such a good deal, but it's really nice not having to pay attention to which port you're plugging in your device, or having to unplug a lower power device because you inadvertently plugged it into a high power port you now need.Considering its tiny size, this is the only travel charger you'll ever need.The front houses five USB connectors; the back a standard AC outlet for the supplied AC cord (should you lose it or forget to take it with you, a replacement can be found in most supermarkets, Radio Shacks, even some dollar stores). I'm using the connector that came with my iPad charger instead; I wish Anker supplied one, it would make the charger more compact and more convenient to take on trips, where cords always add too much clutter (and often trigger TSA bag inspections)I have purchased many high power chargers and so far this is by far the best I've seen. Very small, powerful, more flexible than others thanks to its unique feature, and best of all, it's inexpensive.Make sure you don't buy the 25W model by mistake. It's a little less expensive, but the extra five bucks for this one are well worth it. Very highly recommended.
title: Anker® 40W 5-Port Family-Sized Desktop USB Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8); Nexus and More (Black)

reviewText: Get rid of all those other adapters, once and for all.  This is device is smart... it actually adjusts the power to meet the device's needs.  I know this is true because this the only device I've seen that charge my crappy company-supplied Blackberry.  My older model Blackberry would only charge with low power chargers.  It shut off the charging port on all my other high-powered chargers (I could only charge with a BB charger).  Now,  I can charge my BB, iPad, Android, and any other 2 gizmos I can throw at it.  And, only use one AC outlet.  Don't waste money on overpriced 1 or 2 port adapters, this is all I should ever need.FYI,  I purchased a Bolse earlier, but there's no caparison.  It was 3 bucks cheaper (what was I thinking!?).  The Bolse forces you to use certain ports for certain devices, whereas the Anker does not.  The Bolse has an obnoxious light and is bigger.  The Anker comes in black or white.  Before I switched to Anker, I bought I 2nd Bolse which I had to return because it made a high pitched squealing noise, now I notice the one supplier no longer stocks this device.

reviewText: Edit:  Unfortunately, didn't realize one of the ports was non-functional until after the return period through Amazon was up.  Discovered it when another Anker product wasn't charging. Multiple cable switches later, realized it was the middle port.  Had to disconnect other devices to charge.It's clean design, solidly built. It's a charger, so there's some heft to it. The power cable in the back is detachable, and comes with a velcro strap for easy storage.While that wouldn't make a difference in your final purchase, it's nice to know the packaging is solid, compact, and recyclable.The one thing I'd really like to see on future versions is to have a power switch to control when devices charge Someone else commented about having a means to attach it a wall or a furniture; that would be fantastic.  But those are wishlist items, they certainly aren't reasons to not purchase this version.If you need a charger for multiple devices, this works just fine, and I expect to be using it for years.

reviewText: UPDATE 5/7/14: Since writing the original review and sending the product back, Anker contacted me directly. They asked if I would tell them more about the issue I was having with it charging my iPad at very slow rates and said they'd like to assist me with the technical difficulties I was experiencing with the 5 port charger. They were very friendly and wanted to make it right for me. In the end they asked if I'd be willing to try the charger out again and I agreed. It is rare that a company is this on the ball and goes out of their way like they did to make the customer happy.Again, the second Anker charged my family's smartphones at the correct charge rates. The second Anker, however, charged the iPad 3 close to the charge rate of the 2A power supply that comes with the iPad. With the original Anker 5 port charger I received, my iPad charged painfully slow, at about 9% every hour. That is half what it should be. It was like I was plugged into a 1A charger every time tried charging my iPad. With the new 5 port charger it charged at a rate of 16% every hour. While not quite as fast as when using the 2A power supply that comes with the iPad, it is close enough and very usable.Due to the customer service experience and considering the second Anker I received charges my iPad at near normal charge rates, I'm upping my rating from 2 stars to 4 stars. Had the first charger I received charged my devices like the second charger does, I would have given the product 5 stars. Considering the first charger was defective, I have to take something off even though the customer servicer experience was second to none.----------ORIGINAL REVIEW: Doesn't Charge iPad At Appropriate RateAs a top reviewer I commonly get requests to review USB charging ports, USB car chargers, and external battery units for smartphones and tablets. I've done quite a bit of testing of various chargers for my family's iPhones, iPad, and other devices. iPhones charge at 1% per minute with a slow down once the battery hits 80%. iPhones charge at that rate regardless if connected to a 1A or 2A supply. With a 2A supply the slow down once the battery hits 80% isn't quite as apparent as when charging with a 1A supply. The iPad comes with a 2A supply. With a 2A supply, the iPad charges a little under 1% ever 3 minutes. If the iPad is connected to a 1A supply the charge rate is half that; a little under 1% ever 6 minutes.I recently purchased a Samsung Galaxy S5. The S5 comes with a 2A supply and charges a little faster than 1% per minute with a slight slow down once the battery level hits 80%. With a 1A supply the S5 charges a little faster than 1% every 2 minutes. After adding the Samsung Galaxy S5 to the mix of devices needing charged (also have a Kindle, helicopter, and external batteries), I started looking for a USB charging port that would charge whatever device I threw at it and one that I didn't have to worry about which port I was plugging a device into. Due to the Power IQ feature and overwhelmingly positive reviews of the Anker 40W 5 port charger, I purchased it.The Anker 5 port charger did charge my iPhones, 4s and 5s, along with the Samsung Galaxy S5 at the appropriate rates, based on the power supply that comes with each device. However from the first time I charged my iPad 3 I could tell it wasn't charging at the correct rate. Using the cable that came with the iPad 3, I charged it in different ports, with other devices, and charged it by itself to the same result. Using the Anker 5 port charger, my iPad 3 charged as if it was connected to a 1A supply. It charged at a rate a little under 1% ever 6 minutes. The Power IQ feature didn't work or isn't compatible with the iPad 3. Due to the painfully slow charging of my iPad, I'm returning the Anker 5 port charger and can't recommend it to anyone who has an iPad.
title: Anker® 40W 5-Port Family-Sized Desktop USB Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8); Nexus and More (Black)

reviewText: This is my second attempt at this product. My first order of this item had 1 out of the 5 USB ports defective. No matter what cable or device I used nothing would charge from this one defective port. I then returned it and ordered another and all USB ports worked for the first couple days. Now, again one out of the 5 USB ports will not work at all. This is the second time a USB port has become non-operational for this product and something tells me it has to do with quality control or poor design. I'd like to hear from Anker themselves as to why this is happening and what they are willing to do for me. I want to be able to use this product without worry that it will become defective in only a couple days from using it but so far this has been a very poor experience. I have purchased Chinese ripoff chargers before for older phones that I have owned that lasted years and truthfully never burnt out. I hope there is a good reason for this problem otherwise I can't imagine putting much trust in this product.Look forward to being contacted by Anker.UPDATE: 7-22-2014I was contacted by an Anker rep within 24 hours of my post. I provided my serial number for my defective product, was instructed to keep the defective unit and a new one was shipped out to me. I have received the new product and so far all USB ports are working and I have been using it for over a week. I was told by the Anker rep that there may have been a bad batch reason why I got two defective units in a row. After a week using the defective unit it only had two working USB ports left on it so I trashed it after receiving the new one. I am glad Anker is watching their reviews and they care so much about their customers to do all they can to make things right. I couldn't give 5 stars because of the time wasted on ordering 2 of these and returning my first to Amazon. My main reason for buying this was to use it for a 2 week travel out of the country and I had to use the defective unit for the two weeks I was out of the USA. Luckily the defective unit still worked even it was only 2 USB ports, so it got crowded with all the electronics I had to charge, but I lived. I appreciate all the call backs and emails making sure I received the product and that it was working.

reviewText: I really like this charger.  I bought two others, one is the 4 port plug in type - works fine, but both it an the cable type have a blue LED that gets annoying after some time (would help as a night light though - needed in a hotel room).The Anker 40W has two significant advantages - one is that your iPad can be plugged into any port rather than in specific ports - that is less of a problem if you have different cable types, but if you have iPhones and iPads and all of them have lightning conductors it is a pain to trace back to see which end you plugged the device into - it is not a show stopper but a minor inconvenience.  Also the 5th port could come in handy - e.g. if you have a camera that has a in camera-charger like the Sony DSC 100 series.  The charger itself can deliver 8 watts per device so charging should be fast (I have not tried to test this).  The matt finish is nice, the quality of the cable is excellent (much better than the previous charger I bought) - the cable has a velcro strip to keep it rolled up for travel - again a nice touch.I recommend this charger.

reviewText: The power supply works just great and the PowerIQ function is excellent. It charges my iPhone 4s in less than an hour. However, the  line cord was thick, stiff and cheap material. The connector was the wrong length for the socket on the power supply.Unless you are going to plug this into the wall and never move it, every time you need to deal with that line cord, you will hate it. I actually replaced it with one from a parts bin that was the right size and more flexible. This is an easy problem to fix and hopefully they will do so. Otherwise, an excellent power supply.Followup:I own other Anker products and find them to be well made and useful.The day after receiving this power supply from Amazon, I was contacted by Anker to see if it was satisfactory and I expressed my concerns about the line cord. They were very helpful and while unable to fix the problem immediately, took my suggestions and commentary to their product management.Then, immediately after posting my review, I was contacted by Anker support again and have been in dialog with them since. They have replied personally to my emails within hours and always constructively. They provide direct and personal contact information for your representative which is a breath of fresh air.While I encouraged them to produce a super-premium power supply (and charge more for it), Anker's commitment to customer communication is exemplary and gives me great confidence in purchasing their products in the future. For that reason, I have raised my rating to four stars.
title: Anker® 40W 5-Port Family-Sized Desktop USB Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8); Nexus and More (Black)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Chargers', 'Travel Chargers'], ['Electronics', 'Computers & Accessories', 'Touch Screen Tablet Accessories', 'Chargers & Adapters']]

reviewText: This charger has SMART technology. The 40W is shared amongst all the USB ports. You don't have to pick and choose what plugs into where; just plug in your devices and they will charge at the maximum rates their hardware allows. Other family-style chargers like this have limitations to the ports - certain ports can take certain devices or have current maximums. When I saw that this product came to market without those limitations, I clicked BUY and Amazon had it at my door two days later. I haven't looked back.I dispensed with my 12W iPad AC adapter, my adapter for my iPhone, and all the other wall chargers I had. I am using less wall outlets now. All I need is this Anker charger. As the manufacturer states, it's a little larger than a deck of cards. That's a wonderful tradeoff, however, because I don't need all those damn chargers now. I'm still calculating numbers, as I like to take samples and figure out charging rates, but suffice to say my iPad charges FAST with this.Right now, I have 4 of my work iPads plugged into the ports, just for heck's sake. iPad hardware requires 10W - 12W power to charge, each. There are 2 iPad 4s, and 2 iPad 3s all charging simultaneously, and I am getting normal charge messages on each!Considering how overpriced individual wall adapters are (up to $20 just for an Apple 12W iPad one), this Anker 5 port adapter was a great investment. I will never need to buy another wall adapter, nor will I need to have devices plugged in all over the house because I ran out of outlets in my room.
title: Anker® 40W 5-Port Family-Sized Desktop USB Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8); Nexus and More (Black)

reviewText: I like the relatively minimalist packaging. The power cord is nice as you don't have to worry about blocking other outlets and it allows you to use relatively short USB cables. The cord has piece of Velcro attached to it so that you can wrap the cord to avoid cord tangles. It will be really nice to have a high-power charger so there aren't arguments over who has the high-power charger when we go on trips and we'll only need one outlet. It will also free up our existing chargers to deploy in other places so we have more places where we can charge mobile devices.Update June 2014: we took a trip with this device and our kids brought their own chargers but we wound up using the Anker for all of the devices. We used the following devices with the Anker: iPad Mini, iPhone 5, Google Galaxy Nexus, Google Nexus 4 and Google Nexus 5. I will try the Garmin Forerunner 610 and Jaybird Bluebuds later on.

reviewText: I've purchased three of these now, to replace all of the varied USB chargers that have come with devices over time. I like knowing that I am going to get fastest full-power charging regardless of device, without looking at the tiny port output labels on other chargers. These have worked flawlessly to charge Samsung Galaxy Note2 and Note3, Google Nexus 10 and 7, Kindle Paperwhite and Fire, Kindle Keyboard, many different bluetooth headsets (motorola, Plantronics et al) several different visor speakerphones, GoPro batteries and probably a couple of things I am forgetting.I appreciate the lack of an LED which irritates me in a dark room, and I like the rubberized texture, compact size and well-designed form factor. reviewText: I had some bad luck with 2 defective units. First charger had 2 non charging ports. Second had 1 non charging port. Based on the stellar reviews, I decided to give it one more try. Thankfully, the third charger worked as described. Charges two Samsung Galaxy S4's, Motorola Photon 4G, and Apple iPad 4 without a hitch. The device does get warm, but nothing unusual from other chargers. I used in app charging meters to verify they charge at the same rates as the original phone chargers.Pros:-Compact-Removable cord with cord wrap-2 prong plug (no ground)-5 USB outlets with 8amp total charge!Cons:-2 defective units prior to working unit. Hope this was a fluke and not an indication of future reliability-10amp total for all 5 ports charging at 2amps would be even better! (wishing here...)5/6/14: The 3rd unit I have failed within the 30 day window. It's going back. I was really hoping this product would work well for me considering the stellar reviews and my previous experience with Anker batteries. 1 of 5 ports stopped working again....

reviewText: I bought this for the office but another one will be coming to the house soon.Pros-Its compact as compared to 4 or 5 adapter I previously used to meet the same function.It charges all of my devices at their fastest speed.  Even my extra picky Asus T100, which would only charge at full speed from the Asus plug. (Though the BB adapter would charge it while it was powered, the BB adapter couldn't provide a full 2 amps)Looks good as compared to the 4 or 5 wall warts I used.  With its 6 ft figure 8 cable I am able to attach it to my laptop/monitor riser with some command adhesive and it looks like a built in feature now.Let me reduce significant clutter from my desk by getting rid of a power strip just for wall wortsCons-Can't provide a full 2 amps to all 5 devices at the same time. This is not usually an issue though as 2 of the things I plug in only take 1 amp at a time.It can get a little warm when I have my 5 devices plugged in drawing its full 40 watt ability. Not enough to burn you, but enough I worry the adhesive might loosen up and it will fall to the "shelf" below it.  I've been using it a couple weeks now and that hasn't happened so I think I'll be safe, but maybe an aluminum shell would be better for heat distribution.  To be fair this wasn't made for being glued to things in confined spaces.My co-workers want to steal it.Over all, this is a great device.  Does what it advertises and does it well.
title: Anker® 40W 5-Port Family-Sized Desktop USB Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8); Nexus and More (Black)

reviewText: I owned the 25w version of this, which has specific ports for "iPhone, Android, Samsung Tab iPad" etc. It has done an acceptable job with my devices (multiple phones, tablets, headphones, hotspots, etc - none of which are Apple products); but I would have to play around with the combination of port and MicroUSB cable to get the high power devices to charge at full speed. I saw this 40w version with PowerIQ, and figured it was worth a shot. So far I have not had a single device fail to charge at full speed on it with the first attempt, regardless of cable I grab - it really works! Highly recommend this; it is so much easier than individual chargers. The only thing I wish it had was either some screw slots for mounting or slots to run cities through.. I plan on mounting this to the back of my end table so that the ports are easily accessible, and will have to get creative.

reviewText: First of all, it's a great design.  The footprint is small so it's portable.  It brings enough power to simultaneously charge 4 or 5 devices (including tablets) AND no need to figure out which port is appropriate.What should be improved...  Add four small inexpensive clear soft round 'feet' so the device doesn't slide all over on smooth surfaces.  I added my own and it makes a big difference; but just include the feet and allow the user to add them if it's appropriate fro them.  Next add a small LED indicator on the front of the unit that illuminates when the unit is getting power from the AC source so you immediately are aware it's connected and receiving AC power and devices will be charging without checking them once they are plugged in...  and the kids haven't unplugged the device without you knowing it.What could be improved...  Black and White are OK but maybe look at adding a couple of other colors like red or blue so the unit stands out from other devices in use that are only in black or white.

reviewText: There are a lot of USB chargers out there, but they are not made the same. Most phones will work with nearly any USB chargers. However, I have two devices that apparently very picky in how they are charged. First is the PS Vita. Not any USB charger would work for it, and it is very finicky on which charger it would take outside the official Sony one. Second, is my NEX-5R camera. It is even more picky, wanting to only charge from a lower amperage charger. Most other USB chargers that provide more than 500mA would not work.Enter this Anker USB charger. Not only it can provide enough power to charge multiple devices, the charger is actually smart enough to play nice with my PS Vita an my NEX-5R camera. For that alone, it deserves 5 stars as all my previous 3rd party USB chargers won't work with my NEX camera. Even better, there's no "Apple" or "optimized" port. Just pick any port, they are all smart. Easy. There are enough room between the USB slots to allow different type of cables to fit well. Now I put all my other chargers in a drawer. Just need this one for all my USB devices charging need.Perhaps the only minor annoyance is the extra power cable required to plug the charger into the wall socket. Would be even better if it has a built-in foldable plug.
title: Anker® 40W 5-Port Family-Sized Desktop USB Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8); Nexus and More (Black)

reviewText: I have been anxiously waiting for the Anker smart 40W/8A charger because of it's smart port technology, it would be perfect for my application with a mix of 2A and 1A charging needs. I have 2 Samsung Galaxy S3 phones (1 amp each), one Galaxy Note 8 Tablet (2 amps), one Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 (Verizon 2 amps) and an Asus Vivotab Smart MC400 (2 amps). (2A x 3 + 1A x 2= 8A)Yes I realize that this is a lot of devices for one person to carry but some are for testing, others are for playing. I travel for a living and like having my toys to keep me from going stir crazy in a hotel room in the middle of winter. Simply put, carrying all the different charging modules is a pain let alone playing the "plug in shuffle" with the limited plugs available in a hotel room. With my application, it would be identical to a couple travelling with 1 child, each adult having a phone and tablet and the child having a tablet. A pretty typical situation for the standard family today.I began testing by plugging in all the devices and making sure that they all actively begin charging. They did. I then began testing against the original chargers that come with my Asus Vivotab smart, Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 and galaxy note 8. All 2.0 Amp devices with their own max 2A chargers.My results are established from what is readily available to the common person without expensive monitoring equipment combined with a touch of common sense. The information below represents the Galaxy Note 10.1 Verizon SCH i925 (the most finicky and demanding of the 5) using battery monitor widget by 3c. The display is on, and the application to read the mA is open. The 7000Ah battery is at 92% and plugged into each perspective charger by themselves with no other devices or cables connected.Readings in charging mA in 2 minute intervals, the higher the number, the more power applied:Anker 40W  Samsung Charger+126............+151+138............+172+85.............+281+161............+217+108............+201+157............+265This is just a snapshot of the conditions stated above which would represent me in a hotel room after a day of heavy use, placing it on it's charger and actually using the device. This is a normal condition for me any maybe many others, using it while charging. As you can see, it keeps up with the demand of the device with a bit more to continue to charge. Not as good as the stand alone dedicated charging node, but effective.However, once I turn off the display, the charging rates spike up to +418 mA for the Anker 40W device and +493 for the Samsung Charger, so it is charging at it's max capability while at idle and the display turned off, which would represent coming home and plugging it in and walking away, letting it go into sleep mode and charging. This appears to be the optimal situation for the device and one that most people will likely utilize it for.With all of the devices plugged in, the display's turned off, and in their standby state, they all charge effectively at the Ankers max of 8A and bring them all to 100% with the charger remaining mildly warm and never feeling hot to the touch.If you have this many devices, then this will likely be the charger for you. I will be able to replace 5 dedicated charging nodes, a small 4 outlet extension cable, which combined takes up almost three times the space of the Anker travel charger, and keeps my bag less cluttered.So far I am very happy with the device based on my testing, and hope to have many years of service. They got this one right. Thanks Anker.
title: Anker® 40W 5-Port Family-Sized Desktop USB Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8); Nexus and More (Black)

reviewText: I am very happy with this power supply. No more worrying about which port to connect which device and every device charges quickly. I like the 5 ft power cord versus others that plug into the outlet directly and can fall out with the weight of the USB cords. I was so happy with it I purchased another and suggested it to a friend who bought one also. I have no complaints or negative comments with this device at all, which is rare for me.The price is a bit more than the many others I have bought but I guess you get what you pay for and it was well worth it to me. Prime shipping arrived 2nd day as usual and packaging was great and protected the device well. I would highly recommend this power charger to anyone.

reviewText: I've bought a lot of chargers, hoping to find something outstanding. Finally, this is it. What an amazing device! reviewText: I bought this mainly for when we travel.  Previously I bought a "BESTek" multiple outlet and two (2) 1 amp USB outputs and two (2) 2.1 amp USB outputs with the 30 pin charger for the iPhone with 6 outlets for when we travel, but find that everyone is usually after the 2 amp, faster charging ports.This is the perfect answer to that, since we don't have a need for the 1 amp ports or really a need for the 30 pin iDevice attachment anymore. With 5 cords coming out of this, it did get a little messy, but was extremely functional and therefore well worth it.This is definitely the BEST way to charge all of your devices (up to 5) while you are traveling, or I guess any time for that matter.

reviewText: Generally I am a fan of Anker products,  but I really wish I had read some of the negative reviews of this product. One port was DOA right out of the box. Later in the afternoon a second port failed. I am sure Anker will address it but I would not recommend this particular charger to anyone. The three ports that work, do so very well. I don't have faith that a replacement would make it a year without failing based on some of the other review here. I will update this review if anything changes.*** Update ***Amker sent me a replacement which arrived on my doorstep two days later. I feel this review should be updated accordingly. I really like this charging station better than my  iXCC  Quad USB 31W 6.2A charginer. Unlike iXCC  the Anker product lets you put any device into any port and the charging station figures out how much current to draw.I like this product and would buy it again.

reviewText: No more being forced to use this port for an iPhone, that port for Android, and so on. All of that frustration and inconvenience is history. This product is wonderful: you can plug anything into any port, and it's got a good supply of power (40W) so that everything charges quickly. There's also no annoying lights of any kind, and a five-foot cord so you can put the where you want it and not have to be constantly reaching behind furniture. And Anker is FINALLY offering this in both black and white: what's not to love?I'd love to see this device gain a little more power, so all ports can get at least 10W each. And I'd love to have a small bracket or holder accessory so I can attach this to the back or side of furniture. But those future wishes aside, I love it.

reviewText: This review is for the black version of the Anker 40W charger with Smart Ports.  This sleek devices easily charges pretty much everything I plug in to it: iPhone 5S, iPad 2, Blackberry Bold, TomTom GPS, Philips Bluetooth Speaker,  Kindle Keyboard, Kindle Fire, and my friends' various Android phones.  It's great not having to pay attention to which port you need to plug the device into: this charger will adapt each port to the device and charge it at full speed.The only issue I noticed is with my HP TouchPad: in WebOS mode, it will charge slowly, but when I boot it into Android it will show charging, then stop charging, over and over.  I won't hold this against Anker as the HP TouchPad is very finicky when using other chargers and I am running an unofficial operating system on the device.Overall, this is a great device for charging pretty much everything in your house that charges via USB.  It's small form factor also makes it ideal for traveling with various power-hungry devices.  Nice work, Anker!

reviewText: I have several other USB chargers, single and multi-port. Many of them wouldn't charge my phone at full speed, and none of them would charge my PS Vita at all. Someone suggested I get USB charging adapters for those devices, but that seemed like a clunky solution. Instead, I bought this Anker charger.This brick charges everything - and fast. It is the only thing, other than the official charger - that has charged my PS Vita without any adapters. It charges my Nexus 7. It charges my iPad. It charges my Nintendo DS (with a USB charge cable). It charges my Pebble watch. It charges my backup battery pack. All at the same time. If you can charge it over USB, this will charge it. I take this on vacation, and it is the only charger I need, drastically reducing clutter.

reviewText: I liked the idea when I purchased this item that now I don't need to carry any other charger and I can charge all my devices with one charger in the fastest possible way. reviewText: Have been using the older model that had specific ports for ipad, samsung galaxy, android, iphone etc. This one automatically figures out what configuration will bring the greatest speed to charge your device. reviewText: Had to buy it for a vacation, once I realized I'd forgotten my phone charger at home.  Two-day shipping got it to me quick, and I was ready to go.I would point out that for some odd reason, my Galaxy Note 10.1 (the original, not 2014) would not charge on the dock if I had it plugged in to the Anker, and would give me what looked like an error message.  If I unplugged and replugged the cord into the dock, it would then work.  Odd mystery, frankly; everything else works right off the bat, even my Note 2 in its own dock.Pro: no bright, brilliant light glaring in my eyes when it's on and working.Cons: no way to tell when it *is* on and working except to plug something in.  Then again, it's better than the white three-plug, two-USB I bought somewhere else that has such a bright blue light, it bleeds through the plastic.

reviewText: We have the white version of this that has labeling for different devices. We use it for nighttime charging and it doesn't get hot or anything.This one improves on that by a huge margin by not requiring you to plug your device into any specific port - any slot will do and the device figures out the appropriate charge. That is a godsend late at night in the dark when you're trying to guess which port is the right one.Best of all, I travel frequently and this is internationally friendly. My collegues are very grateful to have an easy place to charge their tablets and phones when this goes onto the table. Plus, with 8 amps, it will charge an amazing array of devices, maybe not 5 iPad Airs, but I have yet to run into the 8 amp ceiling.Awesome device and no issues with either charger yet.

reviewText: I used a USB Power Meter to measure the current when charging and confirmed I'm getting 2 full amps for iPads (2.4 amps with newer iPads) and 1 amp for iPhones.  I have loaded it up and all devices charge at full power, but I don't have enough to attempt to exceed 8 amps (I have up to 8 amps exactly) and it delivers.  I can't speak for non-Apple devices which are supposed to also charge at full rate.With the external power cord design, this is ideal for travel where hotel outlets can be difficult to access and not ideal for brick adapter.  Also, I inevitably have several devices to charge nightly when traveling with my family and it's ideal to carry this one charger and enough cables for each device.  It's not tiny, but it's not big and it's certainly a lot smaller than 3-5 separate single or dual charger adapters not to mention you need additional outlets or power splitters for those.I like it so much I've bought 4 more.  I have one 1 in a couple of places in my house and home office, at work, and one that just stays in my bag for travel.This is the first 5-port charger I can solidly recommend.Update: I've been using several of these for several months and still highly recommend this.  For the price you're getting 5 chargers in 1.  It's more compact than multiple chargers, it's completely versatile, and with it's external cord design you can plug it in anywhere.  I can't recommend this enough.This is THE one to buy, don't get any other.
title: Anker® 40W 5-Port Family-Sized Desktop USB Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8); Nexus and More (Black)

reviewText: This one charger has reduced my bag of chargers and adapters considerably.Hotel rooms are sorely lacking in working electrical outlets, so something like this is a real convenience.It runs on 120 & 240v, so it travels worldwide.  The charger connects via cord, so it doesn't have to hang off the wall or block more than one outlet.With a mix of Android and Apple devices, the smart fast-charging is immensely valuable.Last, it runs fine off the lightweight 120v inverter in some cars, so you can really top off everything on long drives.Good stuff!

reviewText: Unobtrusive! Charge all of my electronics super fast. Works well with HTC, LG, and Samsung smartphones. Also works well with other USB electronics devices (tested Bose BT S2 headset, Kindle Fire, Logitech 700 universal remote, other Bluetooth devices, recharge Anker 12000mAh batter pack) However, I note that it doesn't charge my Asus 2-in-1 T100TA computer. This supposed to put out maximum current on demand per device, but I think either the Asus doesn't have a signal to ask it, or it cannot deliver max current pulled by the Asus. I am still experimenting with different power USB cables, but so far, the only way to really charge my Asus was to use the adapter that comes with the computer.

reviewText: Works as advertised. I'm not going to go into the semantics of putting a watt meter or whatnot on it. All I can say is from an experience IT professional it charged my GS5, anker 12k mah battery pack, a Jackery 15k mah battery pack, and my iPad AIR without flinching an eye. I didn't time it or anything but it go to full charge on all of them faster than I can remember. The unit got a little warm, but for the money it works, and works well.**EDIT**After a week of owning this product the 2nd & 4th ports no longer provide a charge. Using 4 different devices. A GS5, iPad Air, a Jackery Battery pack, and a Anker batter pack. They will all individually charge in ports 1,3,5 but nothing will charge or attempt charge in ports 2 & 4. Went from great to... marginal product. It wasn't dropped, misused, and it has only ever been plugged into 1 AC outlet.

reviewText: The anker 5 port is what anyone needs to charge multiple devices at once. I now do not have to hunt around for chargers and cables.  Very convienent.Speed is great for 1-2 phones but once you start adding tablets it slows down.  Not a problem if you charge devices overnight like I do.Happy.UPDATE:07/15/14One of the ports failed. I noticed this after one device out of 3 did not charge when left overnight. Although the device showed it was in a charging state, the battery capacity did not increase. I switched cables and did it again. Same result.Tried to return via Amazon but missed my window by 2 days. Contacted Anker directly through website and they emailed me back saying they would send out a replacement. No need to return original.To summarize; I still enjoy product and the service provided by Anker. This is my third product from them.  However I suggest that anyone purchasing this should test each port individually. This is what I will do with my replacement.
title: Anker® 40W 5-Port Family-Sized Desktop USB Charger with PowerIQ™ Technology for iPhone 5s 5c 5; iPad Air mini; Galaxy S5 S4; Note 3 2; the new HTC One (M8); Nexus and More (Black)
